HEADLINE: Call It Bush Country 

BYLINE:  By SUSAN WARNER

DATELINE: DEERFIELD 

 BODY:
DONALD JOHNSON, a fourth-generation farmer, has been working the same 1,800 acres where his family once raised row after row of potatoes, tomatoes, spinach and beans for Campbell's Soup, Hunt's and Herr's.
 But forget about tomatoes, potatoes or even cranberries. These days he has a new cash crop -- flowering shrubs, sod, maple trees, coneflowers, lilies and phlox. In all, he tends two million plants that rise up each year from the rich soil here in Cumberland County and end up ringing corporate parks and suburban homes in New Jersey and more than a dozen other states. 
 "They will take all the time you're willing to give," said Mr. Johnson, who tends the land along with the help of 50 field hands, 52 tractors and a vast irrigation system. Yet he has come to the same conclusion about plants as many weekend warriors -- "you can't walk away for very long" -- but for different reasons. 
With wholesale receipts of $306 million, nursery and landscape plants alone make up 40 percent of the state's entire agricultural production, more than fruits and vegetables, livestock and field crops like hay. Retail sales through garden centers and landscapers are estimated at more than $1.2 billion.
Despite its relatively small size and its status as the most densely populated state in the nation, New Jersey ranks 11th among the states in nursery sales, with 866 certified nurseries and 648 plant dealers.
Throughout rural sections of the state, particularly here in the southern end that juts into Delaware Bay, vegetable farmers are converting to the nursery business, which can be more profitable and less risky than growing produce. In turn, new nursery businesses are sprouting.
There are several reasons that this part of New Jersey has grown comfortably into its new role as landscape supplier to the Middle Atlantic states and beyond. It has good soil and a relatively mild winter, and it is within a three-hour drive of 20 percent of the nation's population, allowing plants to get to market quickly. 
And despite that proximity to dense urban areas, this southern corner of New Jersey -- which many would contend sits below the Mason-Dixon Line -- still does not face the level of pressure that is making much of the state's developable land too valuable to farm. At the same time, demand for nursery stock is soaring.
It is the construction of new homes in New Jersey and the rest of the Mid-Atlantic region that is driving sales for everything from shrubs and ground cover to mature trees and colorful perennials, said Dallas Herold, a landscaper in Flanders who is president of the New Jersey Nursery and Landscape Association. 
That is a lot of shrubs, considering that there were 83,090 new home starts in the Middle-Atlantic region last year, up from 75,300 in 1997. In New Jersey the number has declined a bit, to 22,110 new home starts last year from 23,470 in 1997.
"When you buy an older home you can live with the plants that are there until you finish what you want to do inside," Mr. Herold said. "But with a new home there's an immediate demand to get something established in the front of your house so it looks lived in."
Mr. Herold also said local regulations often required landscaping at commercial construction, which has helped increase corporate business.
Indeed, this year state officials recognized the growing importance of the industry and developed an economic strategy for horticulture, including a marketing campaign for "Jersey Grown" nursery plants, similar to the Jersey Fresh program promoting fruits and vegetables.
"The state is going to emphasize its diverse agriculture," said Charles M. Kuperus, the secretary of agriculture. "We are not going to forget the fruit and vegetable farmers as well as those who do field crops and livestock, but in order to have healthy agriculture we need diverse agriculture."
Moreover, Mr. Kuperus said, a stronger horticultural industry could help contain sprawl, a priority of the McGreevey administration. If farmers prosper, he reasoned, they are less likely to sell their land for development.
To that end, Mr. Kuperus said, the state has set aside more than 100,000 acres through its farmland preservation program, subsidizing farmers in an effort to prevent them from selling. He said the state had a goal of increasing preserved farmland at a rate of 20,000 acres a year through 2009.

Help From the State
Along with the Rutgers University Cooperative Extension Service, the state is helping nurture the industry by providing inspections and certification for growers as well as programs to teach them new farming and business management strategies.
"New Jersey is one of the most populated states in the country," Mr. Kuperus said. "We need to do things different here. If government can preserve farms and make sure agriculture is innovative and poised for a bight future, there can be a lot of quality-of-life benefits associated with agriculture."
This corner of Cumberland County, which surrounds Bridgeton, is the epicenter of the state's nursery industry. Millions of plants are grown in long uniform rows, punctuated occasionally by a sprawling Victorian farmhouse or plastic-covered greenhouses.
Amid these vast growing areas, there are few garden centers for those in search of a dozen phlox plants or a couple of flowering shrubs. This is mass production. Plants grown here are sold wholesale to landscapers and garden centers and large chains, including Home Depot.
At Johnson Farms, Mr. Johnson pops into his mud-encrusted pickup truck for a springtime inspection. To the west, sod is being rolled off the earth like strips of used carpeting. He cruises past some of the farm's 300 greenhouses, shrouded in white plastic, where perennials are growing in black plastic pots. He swings past stretches of delicate young trees -- cherries, maple, birch - that are tied to stakes to make them grow straight and tall. Near the center of Mr. Johnson's land is the breadbasket, 200 acres of arbor vitae, the ubiquitous hard-to-kill evergreen.
After 78 years of farming vegetables and field crops, Johnson Farms first planted sod in 1988 and branched into nursery plants in 1990 -- when the Campbell Soup Company closed its production plant in Camden. Then in 1991 a severe drought took a heavy toll on vegetable crops.
"We lost so much money that year we were desperate," said Albert Johnson, Donald Johnson's 81-year-old uncle, who still works the farm. "We needed to change. Financially, it's been wonderful."
Nursery stock is somewhat more resilient to boom-and-bust cycles than produce. When Johnson Farms was raising vegetables, the entire crop would be sold at a price dictated by the processor based on supply and demand of the overall market. In the last year that the farm was growing vegetables, Donald Johnson complained, the price was often too low to cover expenses.
"I just couldn't see ourselves doing the same thing we were doing," said the 49-year-old Mr. Johnson, who began working the family farm during the transition. "Now we have more control." Although he had studied horticulture in college, he said the hardest part of making the switch was learning the Latin names for the plants.
Of course, not everything is coming up roses. Nurseries are much more complicated and difficult to manage. For instance, Johnson Farms must keep a close watch on its inventory of 900 varieties of plants. To do that, the farm operates on a software program developed by nursery growers in Oregon that tracks the location of the various plants on the 1,800-acre spread and how long they have been growing.

Susceptible to Fads
And like many industries, the nursery business is susceptible to fads.
"I have to pay attention to what Martha Stewart says," said Mr. Johnson, a burly, plainspoken farmer who seems to be anything but faddish.
Jim Johnson, Cumberland County's agricultural agent for nursery growers (and no relation to the operators of Johnson Farms), said plants grown in New Jersey were sold in a radius of 250 to 300 miles, extending to Boston, Ohio and Northern Virginia. Up to 80 percent of the landscape plants nurtured in the county are shipped out of state, he said.
Mr. Johnson said the origins of the nursery business in Cumberland County could be traced to the Seabrook Farms Corporation, which pioneered the process for freezing vegetables and later developed Koster's Nursery as a way to diversify its business. The county was also home to operations of the Perkins and De Wilde rose growers.
"Out of those nurseries people got started in the business and then went on their own," he said.
Mr. Johnson noted that Monmouth County also had a strong nursery industry, though he said that it was shrinking because of development pressure.
Whether North Jersey or South Jersey, Mr. Herold said the state's nurseries were known around the country for producing high-quality plants.
"Pricing is higher in New Jersey because other parts of the country don't have the reputation," he said. "Many of the New Jersey nurseries have been in business for generations, so they have trade secrets for developing plant material to a certain size and quality that customers are expecting."
Mr. Johnson, the Cumberland County agent, said that since the early 1990's, about half the increase in the state's nursery sales could be attributed to such perennials as day lilies, hosta and ornamental grasses that were increasingly raised in small, plastic pots under protective plastic sheds at what are known as container nurseries.
For example, Centerton Nurseries in Bridgeton specializes in containers and has developed several trademark varieties that go by the names Hasslefree Roses, CenterPeace shrubs and Happy-Ever-Appster, a line of continuous blooming day lilies named for their propagator, Darrel Apps, another local nurseryman.
Denny Blew, president of Centerton Nurseries, says container growing generates more profit per acre than other types of farming. An acre of soybeans generates $200 a year, while apples will bring in $5,000. A highly productive container nursery, by contrast, can generate up to $50,000. That takes much of the development pressure off container farms, Mr. Blew said.
The container nurseries are constantly working to improve their plants, he said, making them more resistant to drought or pests, or tweaking them to grow in new shapes and colors. "Along with newer, we're also gotten better," he said.
Princeton Nurseries in Allentown, one of the state's best-known nurseries, holds patents on many of its creations. Ivan Olinsky, president of the nursery, said it planned to continue to focus on "bread-and-butter" plants but would put a growing emphasis on rare and unusual plants.
Nurseries are more labor-intensive than other types of farming, said Mr. Johnson, the Cumberland County agricultural agent, explaining that one farmer can tend hundreds of acres of field crops with the right equipment, while a 10- to 15-acre container nursery might require up to 20 workers.
"The Hispanics are a very big labor pool for us," he said, noting that workers from Mexico and Central America performed much of the labor. 
He said the state had pledged to work with federal officials to make it easier for nursery workers to receive temporary agricultural visas.
As for those working in Cumberland County, Mr. Johnson said: "I'm assuming most are fully legal. All of them are required to have documentation, but the growers cannot legally ask or push the issue."
Despite the seeming robustness of the industry, Mr. Johnson said the business went through cycles mirroring the broader economy. When times are good, corporations spend lavishly on plants and homeowners take more vacations, he said; then when the economy is weak, corporations spend less but homeowners spend more on plants because they forgo the vacation and instead invest in gardening.

Strong Season Is Expected
Last year, nursery and gardening sales were down from $315 million in 2001 because of drought, a soft economy and competition from Canadian growers who heat their greenhouses with low-cost electricity, according to the Agriculture Department.
And, Mr. Johnson, noted, the heavy snows and frigid temperatures this winter were tough on the crop. He said the blizzard in February collapsed plastic growing houses in Cumberland County, killing more than 500,000 plants.
"This winter was one of the most severe winters," Donald Johnson said. "But our nursery stock is meant to grow in this area under winter conditions. Everything pretty much has weathered the storm."
He said he thought that this year would be a strong selling season. With the current turmoil, he said he was betting on fewer vacations and more gardening.
His main concern, he said, is that the industry's success will generate too many nurseries that will overproduce and drive the prices of plants to unprofitable levels.
But Mr. Blew is more optimistic. "I'm sure there is such a point, but we're not there," he said. "I've heard that talk ever since I got in the business 25 years ago. New plant material is feeding the market, and there will always be a hunger for new plants."

HEADLINE: UP FRONT: WORTH NOTING; 
Honk if You Want A Meadowlands Rail Line

BYLINE:  By John Sullivan

 BODY:
Imagine the grinding, honking, jolting mass of traffic that pours from Giants Stadium in the Meadowlandsafter nearly every home game. Now add a few thousand more cars wedging their way along highways that circle the area, heading for the new amusement park to be built there.
 It is a picture that has bothered some state legislators ever since the state disclosed plans to build an office and entertainment development near the Continental arena. Now an Assembly panel has begun considering whether a new rail line might be the answer to potential gridlock. 
 "We are concerned about congestion and its impact on the quality of life in the area," said Assemblyman Paul A. Sarlo, a Democrat who represents the area around the Meadowlands. "A light rail would alleviate some of those concerns."
George Warrington, director of New Jersey Transit, gave the panel several options for rail service last week. Mr. Sarlo said the options ranged from a simple $150 million link between the complex and existing transit lines to a $500 million light rail system running through the area.
"We have a major development complex," Mr. Sarlo said. "Now we can complement it with a mass transit option."
Mr. Sarlo acknowledged that the state budget these days had no money to spare and speculated that any financing for a rail project would have to come from federal and private sources as well. But a rail project would not have to be completed for several years, by which time the economy might have turned around and provided more money for the project.
The Assembly panel, which does not have the authority to sponsor legislation or spending, has asked Mr. Warrington to develop specific plans for each rail option. He is expected to do so in about six months.
The $1.3 billion Meadowlands complex, a joint venture of the Mills Corporation of Virginia and the Mack-Cali Corporation of Cranford, is expected to be built over five to seven years.
The companies "are working on a developers' agreement right now," Mr. Sarlo said. "You could see a shovel in the ground as early as next year." John Sullivan

HEADLINE: INVESTING WITH: Phillip H. Perelmuter; 
Hartford MidCap Fund

BYLINE:  By CAROLE GOULD

 BODY:
THE weak economy has made Phillip H. Perelmuter, the manager of the $1.4 billion Hartford MidCap fund, even more selective than usual.
 "Because economic times are tough, if a company's fundamentals aren't good the economy won't bail it out," Mr. Perelmuter said from his office in Boston. As a result, he said, "we're looking for new management coming to midcap companies and accelerating revenue and earnings growth because of their internal improvements." 
 The fund lost 8.4 percent a year, on average, for the three years through March, adjusted for its 5.5 percent front-end sales load, or sales charge. It still ranked among the top 6 percent of all midcap growth funds, which lost 23.6 percent, annualized, during that time, according to Morningstar Inc. The Standard & Poor's 500-stock index, meanwhile, was down 16.1 percent, annualized.
The fund lost 24.1 percent, adjusted for the load, in the 12 months through March, compared with declines of 28.7 percent for its group and 24.8 percent for the index.
Mr. Perelmuter, 42, is senior vice president of Wellington Management, the subadviser of the fund for Hartford Financial Services. He manages a total of $3.8 billion for institutions.
For the fund, he focuses on about 250 companies with market capitalizations of $2 billion to $10 billion that hold leading shares of their markets.
To pick the 90 to 100 stocks in the portfolio, he looks at longer-term economic and demographic trends. The aging of the population, for example, has led him to load up on health care stocks, which account for 19 percent of the fund's assets, compared with 13 percent for his benchmark, the S.& P. MidCap 400.
Mr. Perelmuter uses three approaches to calculate a company's worth. First, he compares its current and two- to three-year projected price-to-earnings ratios to those of other companies in the index. To factor in the company's balance sheet, he looks at its ratio of enterprise value -- which he defines as its market capitalization plus its net debt -- to Ebitda, or earnings before interest, taxes, depreciation and amortization. Finally, he reviews price-to-cash-flow ratios to assess capital spending and working capital.
Mr. Perelmuter asks executives at candidate companies to describe long-term trends in their industries, and how they plan to benefit from or minimize the impact of those trends. He also asks what is most misunderstood about the company, its industry or its products.
It is important for companies to have a simple mission, he said. "We like companies that are focused on one business, not conglomerates with lots of businesses."
When he decides on a stock, he typically starts with a position of no more than 0.5 to 1 percent of the fund's total assets, adding shares as his confidence builds but generally not exceeding 2.5 percent of assets. He reviews a company's shares for sale when management changes or its fundamentals deteriorate.
Mr. Perelmuter started buying shares of Watson Pharmaceuticals, a producer of generic and brand-name drugs, in March 2002.He has paid $27.83, on average, for his position; the stock is now at $28.39.
The initial purchase was made after Watson missed its earnings target in the fall of 2001, following about a decade of steady revenue and earnings growth, and its share price dropped to less than $30 from more than $50. He added significantly to the position when the company named Joseph Papa to the position of president and chief operating officer in the fall of 2002. Watson's revenue should accelerate, Mr. Perelmuter added, because of the Food and Drug Administration's approval in February of its new product, Oxytrol, a patch used to control incontinence.
NEW management also was the catalyst for investing in Mattel. Its chief executive, Robert A. Eckert, was hired in 2000 to refocus the company on its core toy business after losses resulting from its acquisition of the Learning Company, a multimedia game maker. "He's done a truly remarkable job," Mr. Perelmuter said. "It's one of the most impressive internal turnaround stories of the last two years." Mattel now has less debt, more cash, better information systems and good international sales growth, he added. 
The fund paid $17.18, on average, for its shares, starting in December 1999; they are now at $20.93. 
Mr. Perelmuter also likes Lamar Advertising, the billboard company based in Baton Rouge, La. The company has strong profit margins, he said, and typically has huge market share in some cities -- like Jacksonville, Fla. and Duluth, Minn. -- in which it operates.
He originally bought shares in May 1998, paying $36.64, on average; they are now at $33.33.

HEADLINE: POSSESSED; 
Bellows And Barks To Soothe The Soul

BYLINE:  By ELAINE LOUIE 

 BODY:
IN life and in art, Maira Kalman chooses lightheartedness. When Ms. Kalman, the author of 12 children's books, was a student at New York University, she abandoned writing -- and a prose style she calls purple -- and turned to drawing. "I gravitated to people who had light in their work, who weren't nihilists," she said. She loves Duchamp's deadpan irony, Chagall's surrealism, with people floating in air, and Ludwig Bemelmans's Madeline books. "And, of course, Dr. Seuss," she said. 
 Alas, Ms. Kalman was a desultory student, and she had to take a summer class in economics or flunk out. The class was destiny. There she met Tibor Kalman, the graphic designer and a founder of M&Co., a design studio that produced album covers for the Ramones, Laurie Anderson and Talking Heads, and quirky wristwatches, some with blank faces. They married, had two children, Lulu, 20, and Alexander, 17, and each was the other's toughest critic. "The biggest insult was, 'It was a bore,' " she said. 
 In 1998, Mr. Kalman became very ill, and the house was gloomy. "I got Petey for the kids," she said, referring to her sweet-natured Irish wheaten terrier, who, as it happens, is the subject of the book "What Pete Ate From A-Z." "He was a mood elevator." After her husband died, Ms. Kalman made another therapeutic purchase. For $300, she bought a red, two-octave accordion.
Music is solace. Before she became an artist, Ms. Kalman had studied classical piano. When her husband was ill, she listened to Bach and Mozart, and occasionally jazz. "Music had the power to take me out of my despair," she said. 
The accordion, however, was something else. "I fancied myself as a vagabond accordionist, panhandling on the corner," she said, laughing. "I got the idea of being in a girls' band." She could nimbly accustom her piano-playing fingers to an accordion keyboard, she thought, and learn a bunch of folk tunes. Because it wasportable, she could take it to parties. Besides, she liked the name of a particular store: Accordion-O-Rama, then in Chelsea, now in South Amboy, N.J. "How could I not go there," she said. 
But distracted by two new books, the Pete one and "Fireboat," Ms. Kalman put the instrument away for a couple of years. "Then one funny day, I was looking for something new to do," she said. She had heard of Walter Kuehr, an accordionist who gives lessons at Main Squeeze on the Lower East Side. After eight lessons, she learned to play one tune, perfectly. "The Anniversary Waltz." (Oh, how we danced on the night we were wed . . .)
Ms. Kalman has yet to act out any of her accordion-inspired fantasies. Neither has she learned any more tunes. Instead, she has designed a line of raincoats printed with her drawings -- one style for women, another for dogs -- for the Kate Spade label. And a solo art show will open on Friday at the Julie Saul Gallery in Chelsea. 
At the merest provocation, though, she will reach into the closet, pull out the accordion and plunge into "The Anniversary Waltz." What playing the accordion means, even if only one tune, over and over again, is merriment. "It's transporting," she says.

HEADLINE: Business; 
In ComplicatedSkies, Jet Services Gain Members

BYLINE:  By LYNNLEY BROWNING

 BODY:
CURTAILED flight schedules, security worries and a fear of SARS are draining first-class travelers from the major commercial airlines. But those problems have indirectly benefited several new companies that sell multiple flights on private jets.
 Marquis Jet Partners, Sentient and the Delta AirElite subsidiary of Delta Air Lines are among the companies selling these private-jet membership services. These companies essentially sell prepaid blocks of travel on small aircraft -- like Cessna Citation jets that seat six and Gulfstream IV's that seat 14 and can accommodate a flight attendant. 
 Prices vary and can be difficult to compare, but they generally start at about $100,000 for about 25 hours of flight time. Gourmet catering is included. 
While those prices average out to well above first-class fares on scheduled airlines, the companies promote their services as a novel way, amid a sluggish economy and corporate belt-tightening, to fly privately without some of the expense of owning a jet outright or having a fractional share in one. They also bill their newer and plentiful planes as better alternatives to those of traditional charter services.
Sentient, based in Norwell, Mass., said it signed up over 200 more customers in March than it did in the same month in 2002. The company, which TH Lee Putnam Ventures, a New York investment firm, bought this month from a unit of Credit Suisse First Boston and other investors, now has 1,300 customers, divided almost equally between corporations and wealthy individuals. Harvey Golub, the chairman of TH Lee Putnam Ventures, is a former chief executive of American Express.
"People are really looking for security and convenience," said Mark R. Stone, the chief executive of Sentient, which was formerly known as eBizJets. He said the company's total revenue since the week after Sept. 11, 2001, has been about $100 million, and that the company has been profitable since the second half of 2001.
He declined to provide further details, saying only that sales for 2002 rose 78 percent from the previous year.
Marquis, a privately held company based in New York, said its sign-up rate for new members more than tripled in March from the month a year earlier. The company says that it has 600 customers -- about 500 of them individuals and the rest corporations -- and that it became profitable last month, ahead of its year-end target.
Total revenue since it opened for business in June 2001 has been about $105 million, said Kenneth B. Austin, the executive vice president. He added that the company was nearly "one year ahead" of its original revenue projections, but declined to disclose further details.
He said Marquis had been growing so fast because "people just can't get from here to there commercially anymore."
Or at least not as quickly. Major airlines have been paring back their schedules to save money, making commercial flights less convenient for some frequent travelers. Delta Air Lines, for example, cut its regular service by 12 percent last month.
IN addition to offering service on demand, private jet services also help travelers avoid airport delays. The services, including Delta's own, often fly to many of the nation's 5,000 tiny municipal airports and airfields, away from congested commercial-airline hubs and clogged security checkpoints.
Delta AirElite, based in Cincinnati, declined to disclose its revenue or to say how many customers it had enrolled since introducing its membership program in January, saying only that it had received more than 900 inquiries. Cameron B. Gowans, Delta AirElite's director for sales and marketing, said the company hoped that its private-jet membership service, which it calls "fleet" membership, would replace charters as its flagship product. 
Sentient, whose clients include sports stars like Shaquille O'Neal of the Los Angeles Lakers and Alex Rodriguez of the Texas Rangers, does not own any planes; instead, it can charter as many as 1,400 as it needs them. Delta owns four planes, leases five more, operates 20 aircraft owned by others and charters an additional 200 jets through various charter operators.
By contrast, Marquis offers 400 planes through a sub-leasing arrangement with NetJets, the leading seller of fractional shares of aircraft and a unit of Berkshire Hathaway.
Under fractional ownership, customers buy a partial interest in a jet. For around $600,000, for example, they can buy a one-sixteenth share of a small jet, entitling them to about 50 hours of flying time a year. They also pay management fees, typically at least $10,000 a month, and flying fees, usually starting at $1,400 an hour.
Marquis uses the NetJets deal to guarantee that its members, who include Ben Affleck, the actor, and Derek Jeter of the Yankees, always fly on the plane they specify, or one like it or larger.
"You're not going to get a 16-year-old plane that looks like a wrecked prom limo," with frayed carpet and broken seat trays, said Mr. Austin, adding that the average NetJets plane was only three years old.
Some industry analysts say that they wonder if Sentient and Delta AirElite are really just souped-up charter services, unable to guarantee high-quality planes. 
"There's a lot of range of what you probably get in terms of the age and capabilities of planes" with both of the companies, said Barry P. Justice, an aviation consultant in Grapevine, Tex. Chartered planes can be new aircraft with leather seats, laptop hookups and DVD players, or low-technology jets that have been in service for decades.
Starting next month, Mr. Stone said, Sentient's new quality-control team will make quarterly, sometimes monthly, inspections for eyesores like coffee spills. The company has also hired a second, independent safety-auditing firm. Sentient and Delta AirElite also say that they charter their planes only from reliable, well-vetted sources.
S. Jerry Glauser, the owner of a Mercedez-Benz dealership in Sarasota, Fla., said he had flown dozens of times on his $100,000 Sentient card in the last 10 months, including trips to to Aspen, Colo., New York and the N.C.A.A. basketball championship in New Orleans. "It can certainly be luxurious if you want it to be," he said. "Everything has been extremely pleasant, very easy."
MARQUIS may have an edge with its fleet, but some industry analysts question how much the company actually saves some customers. For a corporate client whose executives take trips that require them to stay at a destination for several days, "you might want a fractional instead," said Joseph J. Moeggenberg, of the Aviation Research Group/U.S., an aviation consulting firm in Cincinnati.
Marquis charges from $109,900 to $299,900 for 25 hours of flight time, depending on the size of the jet. It requires notice of 10 hours to send in a plane to pick up passengers.
By contrast, Delta AirElite charges from $99,500 to $245,500 for 25 hours. But members can earn up to seven and a half free hours if they always fly round-trip, so the pilot can wait at the destination. The company guarantees a plane on 12 hours' notice.
Sentient, using a different pricing model, sells travel cards for $100,000 to $500,000, and then debits them at $3,100 to $7,100 a flight hour, depending on the size of the plane and whether the trip's length is short enough that the pilot can wait for the return. On a small jet, Sentient's $100,000 card can buy more than 32 flight hours of one-way trips or nearly 49 hours of round trips. Sentient says it needs booking notice of only five hours.
For all the companies, the most popular destinations are the Northeast, California, Florida and the Caribbean, but they occasionally fly farther overseas, through affiliate charters.
Mr. Stone of Sentient predicted that revenue from private-jet membership services would overtake those of fractional jet ownership, a fast-growing business itself, in five to seven years.
But John W. Olcott, the president of the National Business Aviation Association, a trade group for the private-jet industry, disagreed. "To expect the same level of service and efficiency as in a corporate or private jet," he said, referring to private aircraft owned by the traveler, "is probably unrealistic."

HEADLINE: Personal Business; 
With Interest Rates Stable, Credit Card Fees Rise

BYLINE:  By JENNIFER BAYOT

 BODY:
THE chances are good that something about your credit cards has changed recently.
 If you carry a Citibank or Chase card, for example, your late fees are now based on your outstanding balance; the greater the debt, the higher the fee. Customers of First USA now pay a 2 percent surcharge on overseas purchases, on top of what the credit card networks charge. MBNA and American Express, among many others, are raising interest rates or reducing credit limits of customers who slip up with any other creditors, even if those customers' record with them is clean. 
 Many fees and business practices that were considered unusual only a few years ago are quickly becoming widespread as the card companies seek to build revenue at a time of low interest rates. 
Because of the competitive climate, "you cannot charge an annual fee and you have to offer a low interest rate," said Robert B. McKinley, chief executive of CardWeb.com, which tracks the credit card industry, "so there's been this fee frenzy."
The pressure is on, too, because of the high level of consumer debt and problem loans. The Federal Reserve reported this month that consumers added $5.4 billion to revolving credit in February, and that total consumer debt stood at $1.74 trillion, excluding home mortgages. Last year, though, banks had to write off an average of 6 percent per quarter on outstanding credit-card balances, according to the Fed. At the same time, a record 1.5 million people filed for bankruptcy protection, about 6 percent more than in 2001, according to the American Bankruptcy Institute. The group's executive director, Samuel Gerdano, said it expected that pace to continue this year.
Industry experts say the changing fee policies are intended to hedge risks by imposing harsher penalties on those who make late payments or other missteps and giving more favorable terms and rates to customers with good credit histories. Rajive Johri, an executive vice president at Chase Cardmember Services, the credit card division of J. P. Morgan Chase, said his company has been "extremely cautious in making the changes," but he called them necessary. "Everyone has to follow the competitive trends," he said. Otherwise, he said, banks cannot offer competitively low rates.
Penalty fees are now the third-largest source of revenue for major card companies, after interest and the surcharge merchants pay to accept the cards, industry experts say. For Visa and MasterCard customers alone, those fees grew 10 percent in 2002, to $8 billion, according to a survey published in the May issue of Credit Card Management, a trade publication.
Tiered rates began appearing last year. Since last spring, Citibank, a unit of Citigroup, has charged late fees of $15 on accounts with balances of less than $100, $25 on accounts with balances of $100 to $1,000, and $35 on accounts with more than $1,000 outstanding. By the end of 2002, Chase, Bank of America and Discover, a unit of Morgan Stanley, had followed suit with similar tiers of fees.
Some critics say tiered fees hurt customers who can least afford them, but the companies and even some consumers say they are fairer than flat fees, because they penalize behavior that consumers can avoid -- like making late payments.
A study last winter of 143 cards by Consumer Action, an education and advocacy group in San Francisco, counted 21 with late fees of more than $30. In 2001, the same survey found only one card issuer, Fleet Bank, a unit of FleetBoston Financial, whose late fee had broken the $30 level.
The average fee for late payments is now $30.04, or 6 percent higher than it was last year and double the average five years ago, according to CardWeb. (The $40 late fee could be around the corner: Direct Merchants Bank, a unit of the Metris Companies, set a high mark in 2002 by raising its late fee to $39.)
Other changes in the credit cards' provisions make it more difficult to sidestep the fees. Last year, Bank One, which owns First USA, and Citibank, which owns AT&T Universal, shortened the grace periods on most of their accounts to 20 days from as many as 25. 
Ralph Slate, 34, a database specialist from Springfield, Mass., said the reduced grace period on his First USA card surprised him.
"I pay my bill each month at the same time, online, and was shocked to see that I was two to three days past the due date," he said.
Mr. Slate said that he quickly contacted First USA and averted a $29 late fee, but he said the company's grace-period cutbacks had made him worry about future reductions: "Why not change it to 15 days, or 10, or even zero?" He said he eventually switched to a card with a 25-day grace period.
There have also been changes in fees for overseas purchases. Last April, First USA started adding a 2 percent fee to overseas purchases on all its cards, including its popular Mileage Plus Visa. The currency conversion charge is in addition to a 1 percent fee that Visa and MasterCard have been charging for foreign transactions. Citibank was one of the first card issuers to add its own fee, in November 1998. Now, at least 7 of 10 Visa or MasterCard cardholders pay the extra charges, according to the Nilson Report, which tracks the industry.
Michael and Cheryl Tulkoff of Austin, Tex., said they canceled their Visa card after they noticed the currency conversion fee; they changed to a fee-free card at their credit union. Unlike their other credit cards, the new one does not earn frequent-flier miles or other rewards, so they use it only when they travel abroad.
"Yes, credit cards offer a good exchange rate," Ms. Tulkoff said, but she added that the extra conversion fees made them less of a bargain. "It was like a tax. Obviously, if you don't have to pay it, you try to avoid it."
MANY issuers are also now imposing higher interest rates, or penalty rates, on customers whose credit ratings decline for any reason, including late payments to other creditors. Last month, Chase sent out notices to customers reminding them that they must make timely payments not only on their Chase card accounts but also on all other loans or accounts, even with other creditors, or run the risk of a higher rate on their Chase cards. 
Citibank started such pricing in 2000, and the AT&T Universal Card did so shortly after. The first company to institute such pricing was Capital One Financial, in 1996, according to Linda Sherry, a spokeswoman for Consumer Action and director of its annual credit-card survey.
"It really did alarm a lot of people," she said, "but it has become a general industry practice now."
Ms. Sherry and others trace such standardization in part to the credit card industry's consolidation. Over the past decade, 135 million Americans have had credit cards whose issuers have been acquired by other institutions, according to R. K. Hammer Investment Bankers in Thousand Oaks, Calif. 
"There's not much difference any more between the top 10 banks," Ms. Sherry said. "Now the industry is all plain vanilla."
The convergence may make it harder to shop for better deals when your company changes its fine print. But by knowing what fees are out there, you can still choose cards that are more appropriate for your needs or spending habits. For instance, if you're a frequent overseas traveler, you might apply for cards from companies like MBNA or Capital One, which do not add currency conversion fees. And customers of good standing can ask their card companies to lower their rates or even to revise certain terms. If you start now, the changes could be in place in time for your summer vacation.

HEADLINE: DESIGN NOTEBOOK; 
As Comforting as a Casserole

BYLINE:  By PHIL PATTON

 BODY:
"THIS car is like sushi," a Ford designer, Laurens van den Acker, said of the Model U, a futuristic design study he worked on. With brightly colored parts that can be recycled, the hip Model U was billed as "the 21st-century successor of the Model T."
 By contrast, "this is a hamburger," he said of the Ford 427, a big, square evocation of a 1960's family sedan. 
 Think of it as a game: if a car were a food, what food would it be? 
At the New York auto show this year, the most important new designs aim to reinvent the American family car. Often called the "meat and potatoes" or "bread and butter" of automakers' lineups, such cars seem more and more like comfort foods -- meatloaf or macaroni and cheese for the road.
One comfort car making its debut was the sturdy Chrysler 300C, a big rear-drive model described by its designer, Ralph Gilles, director of design at the Chrysler Group, as "muscular, tall, athletic and noble." Trevor Creed, Chrysler's senior vice president for design, said it had "the proud, powerful lines that once made American automobiles the envy of the entire industry."
The 2006 Ford Futura sedan, present only as an image projected beside the 427 concept car that inspired it, is similarly strong and upright -- another square-meal deal. Chevrolet's new Malibu recreates the family car as a menu of models, from front-drive sedan to a five-door, all-wheel-drive Malibu Maxx.
Like comfort foods, these cars appear warm and filling -- a good value, though not necessarily trim or fat-free.
The comfort they offer is appropriate to a time of vague unease about war, epidemics and recession. Comfort is not exactly security, the value seemingly offered by a tough, military-inspired S.U.V., but it is about reassurance and a reassertion of the familiar.
Back during the war -- last week, that is -- Americans may have shopped less for cars and clothes, but they went out to eat. They dined, however, close to home at "value" restaurants; sales were up at Applebee's, Olive Garden and Boston Market. Since Sept. 11, 2001, comfort foods have been celebrated in cookbooks like Marian Burros's "Cooking for Comfort," and in Iraq the most popular M.R.E. (the military's "meals ready to eat") was hamburger steak -- as close to mom's meatloaf as a soldier can get.
There are few exotic future cars or wild concept cars at the New York show. Still, the "V pulse" key fob of the Volvo Versatility Concept Car literally has a heartbeat. It generates a constant pulse of reassurance that beats faster if something goes wrong -- if someone tries to steal the car, for instance.
Comfort foods tend to be those of shared experiences, of school cafeterias and church suppers. Comfort cars also trade on shared experiences. "Our national character is uniquely comprised of the tension between individuality and community," said Dr. Timothy Malefyt, an anthropologist who studies cars as director of cultural discoveries for BBDO Advertising. "When we go to war, or in other times of crisis, individuality takes precedence over feelings of community." After the war, vehicles like the Hummer, beneficiary of weeks of de facto advertising on cable television, may fade, he says.
"Mostly moms buy these big things in spite of community concerns for harming others on the road, using more fuel," he said. Next, he added, there may be a "swing toward community."
Dr. Malefyt speculated that future comfort cars would appear "hearty and robust." He added: "The current direction of some luxury car interiors, toward cold and gray metallic looks, may be off the beam. Look for supple leather combined with woodgrains and soft plastics."The 300C has tortoise-shell accents.
Casseroles are in evidence, too, as "crossovers" that meld ingredients of S.U.V., van, sports car or sedan. But with each new crossover, the suspicion grows that it is just a station wagon -- that primal comfort car once driven by the primal source of comfort, one's mother.
Maybe mom is ready for a wagon again. Once she parks her Hummer.

HEADLINE: SHAKEN AND STIRRED; 
Care for a Drink Before Your Meal? Sure, but Hold the Meal

BYLINE:  By WILLIAM L. HAMILTON 

 BODY:
AT 7 p.m. on Wednesday in Midtown, what most interested Ven Medabalmi about Citarella -- the $3 million restaurant designed by the celebrity architect David Rockwell and boasting a David Bouley-trained chef, Brian Bistrong, in its kitchen -- was the $12 cocktail he was drinking.
 Mr. Medabalmi, 28, who had arrived with two friends, bumped into another friend, who was there with two companions; they were now a party of six. None of them were headed upstairs to the acclaimed dining room. 
 "I'll grab something later in my neighborhood, something local, something quick," said Mr. Medabalmi, a lawyer, wearing a suit with a dark dress shirt and without a necktie. "I've found that recently, people are not as inclined to go out to eat. Every time you propose dinner, people are like, 'Well, we'll just meet for a drink.' It's less complicated, less logistics. And you can do it more often during a week." 
Mr. Medabalmi said that he chose Citarella's bar because "the atmosphere is clearly nicer" than a standard bar, and "the drinks are more interesting."
Kimberly Sevy, a friend of Mr. Medabalmi who had one denimed leg tucked under her as she sat at the bar, agreed.
"It's very mellow," said Ms. Sevy, a waitress who is also 28. "You have a chance to relax and have a cocktail and be able to have a conversation with people and not scream. Times have changed. We've all gone through something. The economy's not so fabulous, and anyone who lived in New York in the last year went through incredible trauma. When I go out, I just want to spend time with the people I'm with and talk." Yes, Ms. Sevy conceded, "this is a big change for me."
The cocktail's renaissance as a sophisticated way to drink has coincided with a cultural moment -- a hunger for the comforts of casual behavior. Underscored by the economic moment, which is bad, meeting for drinks has produced a new version of the old night out -- not the prelude to the evening, but the main event.
It is not about barhopping, with its mating and dating, or the power and prestige of a 9 o'clock table at the best new restaurant -- sacred cattle of New York City.
It is, instead, an easier, cheaper, friendlier alternative, increasingly popular -- a last-minute plan with lower stakes, higher flexibility, a maximum of social entertainment in a minimum of time, and a sweet lack of stress.
The taste for cocktails, a shaky pocket and an impatience with self-imposed pressures in the face of realer threats are telling many people something that they might have suspected but not yet admitted.
They want the night off when they go out for the night.
"This is not about getting blunted," said Cyndi Stivers, editorial director of Time Out New York, the weekly listings magazine, which is publishing a pocket guidebook to bars on May 23 because, she said, "bars are all anybody goes to."
"Dinner's so intimate," she said. "Bars have a less serious veneer. People are going out in groups now, even on dates, and keeping things casual."
KAREN RAMS, whose hair was cut short and who was wearing a red jersey, said: "I mean, you've got to eat, but reservations? Dinner?"
Ms. Rams, 37, a researcher, was sitting at the bar at Verlaine on the Lower East Side last week, the dregs of a satay plate -- wooden skewer, uneaten rice and peanut sauce -- uncleared in front of her.
"It was definitely the litchi martinis that drove us here," she said. When Ms. Rams, Greg Di Noto and Tricia Melton, three friends who have worked together "in one capacity or another," Mr. Di Noto said, get together now to catch up and argue, agree, tease, take sides, confide or commiserate, they do it over drinks, not a dinner table.
"It feels looser to just have cocktails," said Ms. Melton, 37, an advertising executive, seated next to Ms. Rams.
"There's no set agenda," said Mr. Di Noto, 43, a marketer, on a stool pushed back from the bar between them. "We could decide that we want to eat -- at 11 o'clock."
Ms. Melton, whose hair was long and who was wearing a white peasant blouse, said, "Because I'm married, sometimes we make a reservation." Her voice softened, in explanation. "If we're getting together with couples."
Ms. Rams shot her a look across the bow -- Mr. Di Noto's black T-shirt.
"I live in Brooklyn, which is not an outpost, O.K.?" Ms. Melton said quickly, and loudly.
Ms. Rams, all smiles, said incredulously, "You need a reservation in Brooklyn?"
Ms. Melton regrouped with the last sip from her glass, as the next round arrived.
"The bars are doing a really good job of making it more interesting," she said. "The litchi martini! I thought, 'Never had one -- sounds delish.' "
Mr. Di Noto woke up and said, "Sounds delish?" then burst into laughter as if it were a sudden sweat. "Listen, darling."
Bars introduced an effective concept, the lounge, years ago, with club-style seating and suave lighting for drinkers who wanted mood with their martinis. But restaurants, experts at ambience that were likened to theater in the 1980's and 90's, are facing what E. Charles Hunt, the executive vice president of the New York State Restaurant Association, called "the perfect storm" -- a fatal confluence of 9/11, the war in Iraq and the economy. Fewer people want to be onstage for two hours, eat three courses and pay four figures.
"I've never seen anything like it," he said of the circumstances hovering over the higher end of an industry that now wants a larger piece of the new cocktail bar action.
Mr. Hunt said that savvy restaurateurs are adapting to the strongest areas of the market. "Hopefully, you'll stay for dinner," he said. "But if you have a drink or finger food and move on -- God love you, you're in the chair. The toughest thing in the world in a restaurant is an empty chair."
The average price of a meal at New York restaurants dropped last year for the first time since 1990, said Tim Zagat, a founder of the Zagat Survey and guides. He attributed the decline in part to people's eating less formally, or "bar style" as he called it, ordering smaller, appetizer-size plates.
Citarella, on Avenue of the Americas at 49th Street, which designed the area beside its bar as a dining space in 2001, stripped the starched cloths off the tables when cocktail drinkers moved in instead.
It is not by accident that one ring of the three-ring circus at 66 in TriBeCa, Jean-Georges Vongerichten's latest project and New York's most conspicuous recent restaurant opening, is a lounge, greatly expanded from what would have previously been a basic holding pen for diners with reservations at the restaurant.
In the first three months of 2003, 24 of the restaurants that opened in New York -- 55 percent of the total -- included a substantial bar or lounge area, according to the Zagat Survey, up 10 percent from the same period last year.
"Look at the most popular places, the younger, hipper restaurants, the newcomers," Mr. Zagat said. "There's an effort to provide bar space, lounge space." He cited Blue Fin in the W hotel in Times Square, and the Dos Caminos restaurants, on Park Avenue South and in SoHo, developed by Stephen R. Hanson and his company B. R. Guest. "You can barely squeeze past the bar to get to the restaurant in the back," Mr. Zagat said. "Younger people are socializing in restaurants, but they do less eating."
Danny Meyer, whose popular dining establishments include Union Square Cafe, opened in 1985, and Blue Smoke, opened last year, has increased the space given to the bar at each successive restaurant. Fifty percent of the customers at Blue Smoke's bar are there to drink, not to dine, Mr. Meyer said.
"It's a cocktail generation," he explained. "It's fun -- it's sexy. It's more fun than a glass of chardonnay. People are goingout to socialize over drinks, not the dinner table."
"This recession is painful," he added. "Everyone is trying to figure out how to capture customers. I'm interested in never giving up on fine dining, but I'm interested in being full all the time, too."
Guastavino, the much-publicized restaurant under the Queensboro Bridge, has a brisk evening bar scene. It converted its formal dining room to a V.I.P. bar area two weeks ago after it proved itself more successful as a late-night weekend lounge. Peter Hoffman, the owner and chef of Savoy in SoHo, moved his main dining room upstairs to a smaller space and turned the ground floor into a cafe bar.
"People are changing the way they think about entertainment and dining," Mr. Hoffman said. Saying that he, too, remains committed to fine food, he explained the advantages of a bar clientele: "You can do volume without kitchen labor involved. One guy can make a lot of drinks. I understand why people are in the bar business -- the economics are far better."
Jeffrey Beers, an architect and designer who designed DB Bistro Moderne in Midtown, has spoken with its namesake, the chef Daniel Boulud, about redesigning the front dining room as a lounge, as well as making Daniel, Mr. Boulud's signature restaurant, "more sexy."
"Daniel's getting very curious about this," Mr. Beers said. "You need the restaurant to reinforce the idea that you're not going to a club. But having drinks with friends is very appealing. It's more accessible by more people. Enough with sitting up straight and ordering the right wine."
At Salt Bar on Clinton Street, New York's newest restaurant row, the owner and chef, Melissa O'Donnell, opened a bar that serves food, rather than a restaurant, to hedge her bets. "People don't want five courses, but they don't want beer on the floor either, and if they aren't interested in a meal, they stay to drink and order food anyway," she said.
At Amuse, a handsome lounge and restaurant in Chelsea that was formerly the Tonic until it was renovated and reopened two weeks ago by Gerry Hayden, its chef and an owner, a table of 20 people in their 20's and 30's sat in the bar and lounge area on Wednesday, socializing, drinking and eating side orders or desserts. No one had plans for dinner, not even next door, in Mr. Hayden's attractive dining room.
For younger New Yorkers, the advantages of an evening out over cocktails are distinct: less money, less hassle, less commitment and an ability to get home at a reasonable hour on a weeknight for those many who live outside Manhattan.
"You can get everybody you invite to come out if you just do drinks," said Holly Hunnicutt, 27, sitting with friends and colleagues from the publishing house where she works. "We order 50 baskets of French fries -- that's dinner."
Ms. Hunnicutt turned back to her friends to talk. Reka Simonsen, 32, who was sitting next to her in a sleeveless dress with an ink silhouette on her arm, replied, when asked, "Yes, it's a real tattoo, and yes, it's really Nancy Drew."

HEADLINE: Investing; 
A Storm Watchin the Bond Harbor

BYLINE:  By GREGORY JORDAN

 BODY:
INTEREST rates have been so low for so long that investors may not be prepared for the long rally in bonds to end, many fund managers, financial advisers and bond traders say.
 "The folks who are chasing returns in bond funds are in trouble," said Roger I. Bair III, senior portfolio manager at PSA Financial Center, a financial management company in Lutherville, Md. 
 He added that "the cyclical trend" in interest rates that lowered bond yields and raised bond prices was nearly over. "Going forward," he said, "things will be very different for bond fund managers." 
Investors have flocked to bonds during the bear market in stocks. According to the Investment Company Institute, the trade group for the mutual fund industry, taxable bond fund inflows exceeded $120 billion in 2002, a record. In the first quarter, the surge continued, with an estimated $45 billion flowing into taxable bonds, according to AMG Data Services.
But interest rates, hovering near their lowest levels in decades, are likely to rise once the economy strengthens, lowering the price of bonds and hurting the returns of bond mutual funds. 
Concerns about the economy have weighed down the bond markets over the last month, and interest rates have been little changed since the start of the war in Iraq. The yield on the benchmark 10-year Treasury note has fallen slightly to 3.96 percent, from 3.98 percent on March 19, when the war began, modestly raising the bond's value. Whether that trend will continue in the short run is far from certain, but most advisers and portfolio managers say yields will probably rise, and prices decline, over the longer term.
Bond fund investors can prepare by making sure that their asset allocation is appropriate for the long term, many financial advisers say. After three years of strong returns, the bond portion of many portfolios may be too heavy.
After checking the allocation, investors should make sure they are holding appropriate bond funds, said Sue Stevens, director for financial planning at Morningstar.
Those who have their money in a total-return bond fund -- a general-purpose bond fund that allows managers considerable leeway in selecting the type and duration of bonds -- will have to trust the fund manager to adjust the holdings of specific bonds.
In the current economic climate, Mr. Bair said, managers are likely to sell bonds with longer-term maturities because longer-term bonds are most sensitive to interest rate shifts. If managers anticipate rising interest rates, they generally shorten the average maturity of the bonds in their funds. If interest rates rise sharply, such adjustments are likely to minimize losses, though not eliminate them.
THE largest total-return fund is Pimco Total Return, with more than $70 billion in assets. Over the last three years through Thursday, it returned 9.93 percent a year, on average, about 1.6 percentage points better than its peers.
Other large total-return bond funds recommended by advisers include Dodge & Cox Income, which returned 10.34 percent, annualized, over the period; TCW Galileo Total Return Bond, 10.71 percent; and BlackRock Core Bond Total Return, 9.07 percent.
People who prefer making more of their own investing decisions may have loaded up on funds filled with long-duration bonds, which are more sensitive to interest rate shifts. Those investors may want to consider shifting to short-duration bond funds, Mr. Bair said. 
"The ones to avoid are the long-term Treasury funds," he said. "But one of the things that surprises me is how few people got out of these funds during previous periods of rising rates. You need to get out of them now, before they decline." 
In 1999, when interest rates were rising, the Vanguard Long-Term Treasury fund fell 8.66 percent for the year, while the Vanguard Intermediate-Term Treasury fund declined just 3.52 percent, and the Vanguard Short-Term Treasury fund gained 1.85 percent. In 1994, another year of rising rates, the average long-term bond fund lost 6.2 percent, the average intermediate fund was down 3.85 percent, and the average short-term fund lost 0.83 percent, according to the Investment Company Institute.
Mr. Bair currently recommends T. Rowe Price US Treasury Intermediate and Vanguard Intermediate-Term Treasury. As options, he also recommends Vanguard Short-Term Treasury and Strong Short-Term Bond fund.
Ms. Stevens said that if investors thought their long-term bond exposure was too high, another alternative would be funds made up of Treasury inflation-protected securities, or TIPS. These bonds are guaranteed to rise with inflation (and an increase in inflation would prompt an increase in interest rates). Among the funds she recommends in this category are Vanguard Inflation-Protected Securities, which returned 13.91 percent in the 12 months ending on Thursday; Pimco Real Return, up 13.71 percent in that period, and Fidelity Inflation-Protected Bond, which began operations in June and has gained 1.28 percent this year.
FINANCIAL advisers say conservative investors may want to consider funds that try to reduce interest rate risk through portfolio diversification. Typically, such a fund, often known as a flexible or multisector fund, holds a range of fixed-income securities with varying maturities -- including mortgage-backed securities, Treasuries, and corporate and international bonds. Some of the corporate paper is rated below investment grade.
The highest-return flexible funds in 2003 through Thursday, according to Morningstar, were Merrill Lynch World Income, up 11.92 percent; CDC Nvest Strategic Income Y, up 9.60 percent; Federated Strategic Income F, up 8.77 percent; and Loomis Sayles Bond, up 8.72 percent. 
Daniel J. Fuss, vice chairman at Loomis Sayles, manages both Loomis Sayles Bond and CDC Nvest Strategic Income. In multisector funds, he said, "you have the allowance for below-investment-grade bonds, mixed in with government, investment-grade corporate and emerging market."
"They're very diverse, so multisector funds can adjust to rising rates much easier than most bond fund styles," Mr. Fuss added.
Until rates stabilize, some fixed-income investors may simply want to hold cash in a money market fund. That will not be very profitable -- many funds are paying less than 1 percent -- but it does mean relative safety.
Jane E. Trust, a managing director at Legg Mason, agreed that there was not "much more room" for bonds to continue to rally. "If you really don't want to take any principle risk, most bond funds might be too risky for you right now," she said, adding that in that case, "you should really confine yourself to money market funds."
"People always assume most fixed-income funds are safe," she said "but interest rate risks can always exceed an investor's time frame in most fixed-income sectors."

HEADLINE: Executive Life; 
Washington Insider Heeds a Call to Iraq

BYLINE:  By MARCI ALBOHER NUSBAUM

 BODY:
TIMOTHY B. MILLS is a top Washington lawyer and lobbyist. He is also Lt. Col. Timothy B. Mills, an Army reservist. That combination makes him a player in corporate America, where he advises Fortune 500 companies on military-related matters and the ins and outs of negotiating with the federal government.
 But within the next few weeks, Mr. Mills will be taking a leave of absence from his firm, Patton Boggs, donning his uniform and undertaking perhaps the biggest assignment of his professional life: helping to restore civil order to Iraq. 
 Mr. Mills is one of a coterie of legal experts who will be assigned to task forces created to rebuild the country. He doesn't know exactly what he will be doing, but many matters need to be addressed: restoring the justice system, re-establishing a police force, determining how donor nations will supply aid and structuring internationally binding contracts relating to the reconstruction.
It will be a grueling task. Mr. Mills says he expects to be deployed for a year or so. "Whatever it takes to get the job done," he said.
He comes to the job with diverse credentials. He has been a lawyer of choice for prominent lawyers and for Republican politicians in close races. Mr. Mills represented the Bush-Cheney campaign in three contested counties during the disputed Florida presidential vote of 2000. And he says one of his proudest moments was the successful defense of a former special counsel in the Clinton White House, Lanny J. Davis, now a colleague at Patton Boggs, in a defamation case in 2001.
Mr. Mills joined the Army in 1972 as a federal special agent in the military police and spent eight years investigating cases of fraud against the Army. He joined Patton Boggs as an associate in 1990 and became a partner in 1995.
This will be Mr. Mills's first experience in a theater of war and first trip to the Middle East. In the first Persian Gulf war, he was stationed at a reserve center in Pittsburgh, responsible for mobilizing other Army lawyers. Then, too, he expected to be gone for a year, but the war's swift end cut his stint to two weeks.
Mr. Mills does not regard his lack of experience in the region as a handicap. "There will be cultural and subject-matter experts, translators and people from the host nation who are familiar with the operation of agencies under the Baath regime," he said. "Many of the people who went into Bosnia and Kosovo hadn't ever been there before."
While he waits to be called up, Mr. Mills is briefing the partners filling in for him, studying Iraq's legal system (a topic he researched for the Army two years ago) and logging on to the Defense Department's intranet to review classified military information. He has updated his will and insurance policies and is making plans to rent out his house.
But mostly, he is thinking about a country that has never known democracy. "The biggest challenge is to restore or actually create what the people of Iraq will accept as a legitimate government that respects their interests," he said. "Since the Baath Party took over in the late 1960's, Iraq has had a single-party government modeled after Stalin's Soviet Union. In addition, all the organs of government that we think of in the West as being fair have become instruments of repression."
MR. MILLS said the lawlessness that has been on view in several Iraqi cities was an immediate concern. "If you looked at news reports from Basra, parts of Baghdad and other cities where Baath authority has been displaced, you saw that with the authority removed, there is a vacuum," he said. "With no public safety, no operating police, no economic system and no courts, what you have is looting and chaos, and possibly violent crimes. So the first step will be to restore public safety."
That will require removing what remains of the secret police and militias, he says, and replacing them with an interim security force of troops from several countries, but also including Iraqis. Another challenge is to persuade Iraqis to accept the interim authority as legitimate, he said; in this regard, America's experience in other countries could be instructive.
For example, in Bosnia and Kosovo, the public did not initially perceive outsiders as having moral authority. "So one thing you have to look at is how to involve troops or others with a cultural background similar to the Iraqis in those policing activities," Mr. Mills said. "Other nations in the Islamic world might play a role here."
Asked whether the United Nations would be the vehicle for other nations to become involved, he said he was not in a position to give the official United States view, but he offered some of his own thoughts.
"It's not surprising that Senators Warner and Biden and the administration all agree that the U.N. should have a significant role as a partner, but not as a managing partner," he said, referring to John W. Warner, Republican of Virginia, and Joseph R. Biden Jr., Democrat of Delaware. "The U.N. is perfectly positioned to provide humanitarian assistance through its oil-for-food program, and it has resources it can marshal that should and must be used to restore life in Iraq, not to what it was but what it should be."
Juggling a military and civilian career has not been without cost to Mr. Mills. While he is close to his three children, now well into their 20's, he says they have told him that they wish he had been around more when they were growing up. And he fully expects that his current mobilization will result in lost income well into six figures.
Yet he does not question his commitment to the Army. "If I'm called upon to serve my nation in a time of national need, then it's very similar to taking a sabbatical," he said. "I also think it's a rare opportunity to make a contribution to stability in the gulf region -- and we'll see whether that becomes a model throughout the Middle East."
Besides, he said, "I believe that in the long term my clients will remain loyal to me when I return."

HEADLINE: Business; 
A Town's Protests Threaten Argentina's Mining Future

BYLINE:  By LESLIE MOORE

DATELINE: ESQUEL, Argentina 

 BODY:
JUST a month ago, investors were buzzing about gold buried in the hills and dells of Patagonia, and government officials were predicting that surging gold prices and Argentina's cheap peso would stoke a boom in mining and attract billions of dollars.
 But after voters in this mountain town turned against a $720 million gold and silver mine to be built by Meridian Gold, a mining company based in Reno, Nev., investors are thinking twice about mining in Argentina. 
 "The worry is that antimining forces will spread," said Jose Luis Andrich, who publishes a mining newspaper called Prensa Geo Minera. "This puts at risk all future mining investment in Argentina." 
Instead of tending to new exploration, "we'll have to row against antimining currents," said Victor Bonfils, who supervises Argentina mining properties at Rio Tinto, a mining conglomerate based in London.
In the referendum, on March 23, a broad coalition of residents here in Esquel (pronounced Ess-KELL) voted against Meridian's project, called El Desquite (Des-KEY-teh), which would be about six miles from town. Opponents said the mine could pollute the water supply in this tourist town at the base of the Andes, 1,200 miles southwest of Buenos Aires and near Los Alerces National Park. Others said Argentina's mineral wealth should be harnessed by Argentines.
Streets and walls in this community of 29,000 are scrawled with antimining graffiti, and armed police have guarded Meridian's downtown office. The company said a Molotov cocktail was hurled at a car owned by a driller. Both mine opponents and advocates say they have received threatening phone calls. 
The referendum holds no legal sway, but the drubbing of Desquite has shaken the political establishment. After the vote, Gov. Jose Luis Lizurume of Chubut Province, which includes Esquel, asked Meridian to halt work on the mine until the company completed an environmental study; provincial authorities had already approved the project. Many people here want Meridian to abandon the project and leave town.
Meridian has stopped construction and is studying how the project may affect local water supplies. After opposition swelled, the company volunteered to establish a fund to cover incidental environmental harm.
Meridian arrived here last year after buying a $320 million, 543-acre site, which it estimates contains three million ounces of gold. The company said it planned to spend $400 million more during the mine's operations, paying monthly wages of about 900 Argentine pesos, or about $308, well above a poverty-level salary, to 400 people.
Mining analysts fault Meridian for bungling relations with the town. "It was as if everything Meridian said was said on purpose so people would get angry," said Maria Cecilia Ubaldon, a state-employed geologist and Esquel resident who favors the mine.
Gustavo Manuel Macayo, who runs a family-owned bookstore, said: "People didn't oppose the mine -- they were indifferent. But from the start, Meridian imposed the project on Esquel. If the mine is built, it will provoke a war here."
Darcy Marud, Meridian's exploration manager, said an "anti-gringo" backlash had fed a firestorm of protest. "People feel damaged by what happened to the Argentine economy," he said. "They see some of their problems as forced upon them by the U.S. and other gringo powers."
The vote against the American company came four days after the start of the war in Iraq and amid protests against the United States Embassy in Buenos Aires. Local radio stations have broadcast messages saying "we're for peace and against the war" and local newspapers have published photographs of war casualties on their front pages.
"It was as if those who voted against the project saw it as a town's triumph of anti-imperialism," said Elina Gil, a Meridian geologist.
Many Argentines are still bitter about the government's sale of oil, natural gas and telecommunications assets in the last decade. They say the sales helped tip the country into turmoil.
Argentina's currency lost nearly 70 percent of its value after the devaluation in 2002, and the economy shrank 12 percent for the year. The economy is rebounding -- industrial production has increased for two quarters and exports have surged -- but Argentina still has an unemployment rate of 22 percent.
THE Esquel debacle could reverse a growing euphoria about Argentina's gold prospects. Small armies of geologists are digging for gold across Patagonia after recent discoveries, and a flurry of deals have closed since the peso stopped trading one-to-one with the dollar in January 2002.
Buenaventura Mining, a Peruvian company, formed a joint-venture deal with Yamana Resources Inc. of Canada last year to scout for gold and silver. "It was absolutely the peso devaluation that led to this deal," said Raul Bonfada, vice president for Yamana's Argentina operations. The devaluation lowers labor and other costs.
But the Esquel referendum has made many companies leery, said Patricio Jones, an exploration geologist. "There's a tremendous fear this will affect other provinces," said Mr. Jones, president of Desarrollo de Prospectos Mineros, which is scouting for gold in Santa Cruz Province in Patagonia.
Patagonia Gold, a company partly owned by HPD Exploration of London, has stopped prospecting in Chubut Province, said a vice president, Gonzalo Tanoira. "It's no use exploring if you can't turn the land into a mine," he said.
