HEADLINE: Arafat and Premier Break Deadlock Over Cabinet 

BYLINE:  By JAMES BENNET 

DATELINE: RAMALLAH, West Bank, Thursday, April 24 

 BODY:
Under intense international pressure, Yasir Arafat and the Palestinian prime minister, Mahmoud Abbas, agreed Wednesday on a compromise cabinet for the governing Palestinian Authority, breaking a 10-day stalemate that has delayed the introduction of a new Middle East peace plan. 
 Mr. Arafat forced Mr. Abbas to promote a few of his longtime allies. But he allowed the inclusion of Muhammad Dahlan, a security official favored by the United States and Israel as willing to crack down on Hamas and other militant Palestinian groups. 
 Whether Mr. Dahlan and this new government will prove willing or able to act on security or civic reform was left uncertain by Wednesday's agreement, a tottering balance of the powers of Mr. Arafat and Mr. Abbas that portend more Palestinian instability. 
In a sign of the obstacles facing any new effort, a suicide bomber set off a device early this morning outside a commuter train station in the Israeli town of Kfar Saba. The bomber and at least one other person were killed and several more were wounded, according to initial reports from rescue workers.
The new peace plan, which has been repeatedly postponed by the Bush administration, was drafted in December by the so-called quartet of the United States, United Nations, European Union and Russia. It calls for simultaneous concessions by both sides that would progress to a resolution of all disputes and an independent Palestinian state in three years. 
In the first phase, for example, the Palestinians are required immediately to "undertake visible efforts on the ground" to stop violence, while the Israelis are required to dismantle settlement outposts built in the last two years. Israel is seeking changes in the plan.
Secretary of State Colin L. Powell is expected to travel to the region in the first week of May to push the plan. He is also expected to travel to Jordan, Egypt, Saudi Arabia and Syria to discuss how Arab nations can support the plan.
But to meet President Bush's condition for proceeding with the peace plan, the cabinet must now be confirmed by the Palestinian parliament, which is expected to consider it next week. Palestinian officials and legislators, as well as foreign diplomats, said that confirmation was not assured, because Mr. Abbas and Mr. Arafat have agreed on some ministers whom legislators consider incompetent or corrupt. 
Ari Fleischer, the White House spokesman, said the Bush administration hoped for prompt confirmation of the new cabinet. He said the United States would then put its "shoulder to the wheel" to help make the peace plan work. 
Over the long term, Wednesday's development pointed toward the erosion of Mr. Arafat's pre-eminence, since it appeared to help institutionalize the post of prime minister. For 30 years, Mr. Arafat maintained authority by finely rationing power beneath him, preventing the ascendance of a clear No. 2. 
"This is the essence of power sharing, of partnership," said Nabil Shaath, who was designated as foreign minister, in announcing the agreement Wednesday.
But it seemed a lopsided partnership, one that favored Mr. Arafat, at least for now. 
Mr. Arafat scored more on style than substance. The compromise list of 24 ministers differed by only a few members from the one Mr. Abbas compiled 10 days ago, and it included some reformers he had previously left out, along with allies of Mr. Arafat he had tried to demote. Some associates of Mr. Abbas argued that he wound up looking tough, for having held on to Mr. Dahlan.
But by ostentatiously yielding to foreign demands, Mr. Arafat sharpened Mr. Abbas's image among Palestinians as the candidate of outside interests. Some reform-minded Palestinian officials said that Mr. Abbas had emerged from the fight looking so weak that they might have preferred no resolution, and Mr. Arafat naming a new prime minister instead. 
"He was outmaneuvered easily," one of these officials said of Mr. Abbas, who is known as Abu Mazen. 
By forcing Mr. Abbas to rework his cabinet list and stretching the fight out almost until the legal deadline of midnight tonight, Mr. Arafat also reminded the world, at whatever cost to Palestinian governance and hopes for peace, that he had not yet become irrelevant, as Israel declared him to be in December 2001.
"All that's proved in the last two or three weeks is that Yasir Arafat is simply there, and his presence is very much felt," said Maher Masri, the reform-minded minister of trade, economy and industry.
Nabil Aburdeineh, a close aide to Mr. Arafat, referred to American and Israeli officials in saying, "You have seen in the last five weeks, all of us are taking orders from Arafat, whether they like it or not."
Raising a hand toward the bullet-pocked face of Mr. Arafat's compound, newly outfitted with steel shutters, Mr. Aburdeineh said that it did not matter if Mr. Abbas or other officials and not Mr. Arafat were invited to negotiate abroad. "Let them go to Washington and Amman," he said. "Nothing will be solved without coming to this ruined room."
More than a week's worth of diplomatic cajoling and threatening of Mr. Arafat culminated in the arrival here Wednesday of Omar Suleiman, the Egyptian intelligence chief, who was dispatched by President Hosni Mubarak in consultation with United Nations diplomats and others. 
Mr. Suleiman shuttled between the offices of the two men before finally coaxing Mr. Abbas to Mr. Arafat's side late Wednesday afternoon. They were last together on Saturday evening, when Mr. Abbas stormed out of Mr. Arafat's office, threatening to abandon his efforts.
Shortly after Mr. Abbas and Mr. Suleiman went inside, reporters were admitted to see Mr. Arafat seated between the two men, clasping each by the hand and beaming as he declared an agreement. 
Mr. Abbas, a reserved man who has evinced little of Mr. Arafat's political skill, common touch or ruthlessness, was not smiling.
Mr. Abbas composed his initial list in secrecy and remained secluded through the talks. He refused to speak to reporters as he left Wednesday, with Mr. Arafat maintaining his firm grip on his hand. 
"You lost your chance for me to talk," was all Mr. Abbas said, as he gestured at a scrum of wildly shoving journalists and climbed into a black Mercedes sedan. 
Later, Mr. Abbas released a statement in English, suggesting that the ministerial choices were his alone. "I am very pleased that my cabinet has received the support of President Arafat," he said. "The agreement on the cabinet marks a victory for the Palestinian people as it demonstrates our commitment to democracy, even as we live under Israeli occupation."
Mr. Abbas founded the mainstream Fatah movement with Mr. Arafat but for 40 years has remained in the shadow of his friend and rival. He has almost no popular following. Palestinian analysts said he would quickly generate some enthusiasm if he achieves tangible benefits for Palestinians, like an easing of Israeli checkpoints and other restrictions.
Leaders of Hamas pounced on the role of foreigners to question the legitimacy of the new government. "The appointment of the prime minister was based on foreign interference," said Mahmoud Zahar of Hamas. "The forming of this new government is also based on foreign interference." That was why, he said, "the Palestinian street is shocked."
Rising leaders of Fatah -- who brought down a previous Arafat government in September and pushed through legislation last month to create a strong prime minister -- were also disappointed.
"What happened was a stumble and not an achievement," said Qadoura Fares, a legislator from Fatah, ascribing the failure to Mr. Abbas and Mr. Arafat. "We built hopes on Abu Mazen of creating serious change. The change was not substantial, not what we were looking for."
Several crucial details about the new government were left vague today: first among them, who would arbitrate future disputes between the president and prime minister. "God Almighty," replied Mr. Shaath, grinning and rolling his eyes skyward, when asked who would decide.
Further, the appointment of Mr. Dahlan did not clarify the question of who is ultimately in charge of security. Mr. Abbas has kept for himself the Interior portfolio, which oversees most security matters. Mr. Dahlan is to hold the title of state minister for security affairs.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Mahmoud Abbas, left, the new Palestinian prime minister, and Muhammad Dahlan, right, who was named security minister as part of a compromise on forming a cabinet, in Ramallah with Yasir Arafat. (Agence France-Presse)

HEADLINE: Sports of The Times; 
New Address For Nets: The Garden?

BYLINE:  By HARVEY ARATON 

 BODY:
A NEW arena in Newark, that's still the ticket, proclaimed David Stern. "We're standing in the oldest unremodeled arena in the N.B.A.," the always informative commissioner said Tuesday night at Continental Arena, which opened in ancient times, 1981, bearing the name of Brendan Byrne.
 Amid the worst state and municipal budget crises anyone can remember, Stern wants New Jersey to go ahead with a plan that was formulated when government was awash in a surplus, when head-spinning promises could be passed around like nifty assists from Jason Kidd. 
 Seems like yesterday that one of the Nets' owners, Lewis Katz, stood alongside President Clinton at Malcolm X Shabazz High School in Newark and said the Nets were coming, they would pay a healthy share of the arena's costs and the ailing city could bank on 40 percent of future profits. 
That was before the financial realities of professional sports ownership in tepid suburbia dawned on George Steinbrenner. Before he became the muscle behind the basketball and hockey franchises, not his YankeeNets partners, the self-styled philanthropists from New Jersey.
Yesterday, three and a half years after Katz stumped with Clinton for urban renewal, The Star-Ledger of Newark reported YankeeNets' latest arena proposal: Newark puts up $355 million through diverse financing. YankeeNets pays back a third of that amount over the next three decades. 
"There are deals to be put together even in difficult economic times," Stern said. This latest YankeeNets offer goes beyond difficult and insulting, all the way to insane. It is, quite possibly, an indication that Steinbrenner wants a way out because he doesn't believe the suburbs -- any of them -- will ever make sufficient dollars and sense. 
While Stern did not sound enthusiastic about a Meadowlands renovation, somebody needs to at least discuss an alternative, at least before this summer, when Kidd will decide whether to solidify the Nets' competitive future or leave them as pointless as their past.
Tony Parker's playoff misadventures in San Antonio aren't helping. Kidd has already expressed intrigue over playing with the Spurs' Tim Duncan. There is a shadow coming upon the Nets that is far more ominous than Gary Payton as their deadlocked first-round playoff series with the Bucks shifts to Milwaukee tonight for Game 3.
"This franchise is fine," Stern argued before the Nets' lost their home-court advantage. "Their gate is actually pretty strong."
Red ink aside, the Nets are certainly not the unloved and unwatched Atlanta Hawks or Cleveland Cavaliers. Conversely, in a season in which they were the defending Eastern Conference champions, fielding an attractive team to the critical eye, the Nets were outdrawn by one of the tenants of the Staples Center in Los Angeles, not the Lakers.
Look it up. The woeful Clippers were 14th in home attendance, averaging 17,231. The Nets, while on the upswing from last season and increasing their earnings with higher ticket prices, were still only 23rd in attendance, averaging 15,184.
Such is the advantage of playing in the middle of the metropolis, even one governed by freeways, and it begs the question of why Steinbrenner, now that he and the Dolans have again become best cable buddies, hasn't followed the Clippers' lead.
A move by the Nets to the Dolan-owned Madison Square Garden would thrill Kidd and wouldn't hurt the budding television career of his wife, Joumana. It would give the Nets a big-city buzz. All these years, Nets officials have wished to be up when the Knicks were down, but what they have learned about widespread appeal is that when the Knicks are down, pro basketball in the metropolitan area is pretty much out.
What would be in it for the Dolans? A negotiated lease, more revenue for their own sagging financial fortunes, improved odds that their building, come playoff season, wouldn't be as dark and lifeless as a looted palace of Saddam Hussein.
The Newark arena was a good idea, a worthy cause, under the old conditions. The notion of taxpayers of a state that is broke being shaken down is fiscally appalling and morally wrong. New Jersey can't afford to flatter George Steinbrenner and his YankeeNets friends with a luxury-box palace any more than New York can build him a new ballpark in the Bronx.
"This arena is fine for now," Stern said Tuesday night, "but it is not a long-term solution." Fine. Let him sit down between Steinbrenner and the Dolans and come up with a plan. As old as the renovated Garden is and as mediocre as its main act may be, it is still the fanciest address in the N.B.A. and the best place for more basketball games.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Jason Kidd (Barton Silverman)

HEADLINE: Republicans Have Tax-Cutting Ax to Grind With One Another 

BYLINE:  By DAVID FIRESTONE 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, April 23 

 BODY:
Bitter about the success of Republican moderates in whittling down President Bush's tax cuts, Republican conservatives are planning to exact a political price for what they consider to be economic heresy.
 One prominent Republican senator who opposed the administration's first tax cut, Arlen Specter of Pennsylvania, is already facing an aggressive primary challenge from Representative Patrick J. Toomey, a vocal supporter of larger tax cuts. Senator John McCain of Arizona, who voted against this year's proposed cut, may also face a primary challenger. 
 Conservatives are also recruiting candidates to run against several moderate House members whom they consider to be liberal spenders. 
Already, the intensity of feeling among party members on both sides of the tax cut debate has deepened an unusually public and acrimonious rift between two prominent Republican institutions: the Republican Main Street Partnership, which represents about 65 centrist members of Congress and governors, and the Club for Growth, a conservative political action committee supporting the administration that has taken on moderates with increasing ferocity.
Last week, the Club for Growth began running television commercials attacking two Republican senators, George V. Voinovich of Ohio and Olympia J. Snowe of Maine, who have joined Democrats to hold Mr. Bush's tax cut to $350 billion, less than half of the president's original proposal. 
The advertisements compared the senators to the French leaders who opposed the invasion of Iraq, and accused them of "standing in the way" of the president's plans to fix the economy.
This week, the moderates began to fight back. Over the weekend, the Main Street Partnership began running its own newspaper and television advertisements in Maine defending Ms. Snowe, a member of its board, and criticizing conservatives who support bigger deficits. The advertisements said Ms. Snowe was trying to preserve federal dollars for the president's spending priorities, as opposed to "the wealthy Wall Street denizens Club for Growth represents."
The partnership also plans an unusual joint effort with the Service Employees International Union, a liberal labor organization, running a television commercial in Maine thanking Ms. Snowe for devising a budget compromise "that kept more money for education, health care and prescription drugs, while keeping the federal deficit from growing even larger."
The Club for Growth, which many moderates say operates with the tacit endorsement of the White House, says it has two goals: to get the votes the president needs for passage of a large tax cut in a few weeks and to replace as many centrist Republicans as possible. 
But the challenges from the right in the Republican primaries, on which the club plans to spend heavily, also have the effect of warning members of Congress what awaits them if they stray from the party line.
Stephen Moore, president of the club, said Mr. Toomey's challenge to Mr. Specter forced Mr. Specter to vote for the full tax cut earlier this month, even though he had opposed the 2001 cut. 
Other possible primaries, along with the advertisements, may produce a similar result in the coming vote on the final tax cut, Mr. Moore said.
"The White House does the cajoling," he said. "We use the hammer."
Democrats, naturally, are delighted at the prospect of intra-Republican feuding that may create an opening for them in some races. Democratic operatives are scurrying to find a candidate to run against the winner of the Senate primary in Pennsylvania next year and are issuing flurries of press releases documenting what they say is Mr. Specter's move to the right in anticipation of the primary.
Although Mr. McCain is considered less vulnerable than Mr. Specter, Representative Jeff Flake, a conservative, is contemplating a run against him.
Mr. Moore said the club was also considering backing Republican challengers to several moderate House members, including Representatives Sherwood L. Boehlert and Amo Houghton of New York and Wayne T. Gilchrest of Maryland.
Senator Jon Corzine of New Jersey, chairman of the Democratic Senatorial Campaign Committee, said: "To the extent that there is discord among Republicans on these economic issues, that's good for the Democrats. The primary will pull Senator Specter back toward supporting fiscal policies that have failed, and the increase in unemployment in Pennsylvania under this administration is a real meat-and-potatoes issue for Democrats to talk about."
Mr. Moore said his group carefully chose its targets to ensure that Democrats did not end up benefiting from primaries. And some conservatives say the fight is worthwhile even if a Democrat does win. Mr. Flake, who is close to the club, said there would be little difference in his mind between Mr. Specter and a Democrat.
That sentiment -- which Mr. Boehlert calls the "purity test" -- appalls Republican moderates.
"How can he say that and be a good Republican?" said Sarah Chamberlain Resnick, executive director of the Main Street Partnership. "A loss to the Democrats in Pennsylvania could flip control of the Senate. I just don't understand that kind of thinking."
Republican conservatives, however, cannot contain their frustration at being unable to pass the president's full economic plan despite having won control of both houses of Congress last fall. In a sense, they have already changed the terms of an earlier debate 20 years ago, when Rockefeller Republicans argued with Reagan Republicans over whether there should be any tax cut. Now, a victory for moderates would be a $350 billion tax cut, but conservatives, having come within a few votes of their goal, want the full prize.
"The vast majority of Republicans now come down on the side of maximizing economic growth by reducing taxes," said Mr. Toomey, who has already raised more money than the combined total of Mr. Specter's previous primary challengers. "Now we're only two votes from bringing the Senate more in line with the House, and Senator Specter has clearly been out of step on the whole issue of taxes."
Mr. Specter denied that he had supported this year's tax cut because of the primary race. He opposed the last tax cut because it was too big and would have taken money away from education, he said, but voted for the full $726 billion this year because he believed that the faltering economy needed a bigger stimulus.
"As soon as you're up for re-election, it's a great American pastime to challenge your motivation," Mr. Specter said. "I usually try to be a team player and help the party. But I think these Club for Growth people underestimate the importance of independence in an elected representative. As Kennedy said, 'Sometimes the party asks too much.' "

GRAPHIC: Photo: George V. Voinovich of Ohio, shown here at a Cleveland food bank on Tuesday, is one of the Republicans under attack by conservatives within the party. (Associated Press)

HEADLINE: ART GUIDE 

 BODY:
 A selective listing by critics of The Times of new or noteworthy art, design and photography exhibitions at New York museums and art galleries this weekend. At many museums children under 12 and museum members are admitted free. Addresses, unless otherwise noted, are in Manhattan. Most galleries are closed on Sundays and Mondays, but hours vary and should be checked by telephone. Gallery admission is free. * denotes a highly recommended show.

Museums

* "MATTHEW BARNEY: THE CREMASTER CYCLE," Solomon R. Guggenheim Museum, 1071 Fifth Avenue, at 89th Street, (212) 423-3500 (through June 11). The most anticipated show by any American artist to emerge in a decade or more. "Cremaster," Mr. Barney's nine-year, five-film project, here presented whole for the first time, is an inspired benchmark of ambition, scope and forthright provocation for art in the new century. I recall Elizabeth Murray's describing how Philip Guston's crazy late works gave her heart to do her own mature paintings. Mr. Barney has brought to the art world a new freedom to explore narrative. He has introduced a new repertory of materials, gooey, strange, malleable and synthetic, which nobody thought of as germane before. Never mind that the films and many (not all) of his related sculptures, installations and photographs are very beautiful. The show, an installation itself, brings them together. The earliest "Cremaster" sculptures are film props, cobbled into installations that don't jell. But the latest are better: twin steel towers framed in plastic, a suite of abstract sculptures derived from automobile chassis. Vaseline and plastic combine with cement and steel -- pink and gray, rough and smooth, hard and soft -- the materials sustaining a narrative of formal eloquence. Hours: Saturdays through Wednesdays, 10 a.m. to 5:45 p.m; Fridays, 10 a.m. to 8 p.m. Admission: $15; $10 for students and 65+ (Michael Kimmelman).

* "EGYPT REBORN: ART FOR ETERNITY," Brooklyn Museum of Art, 200 Eastern Parkway, at Prospect Park, (718) 638-5000 (permanent installation). The second and final phase in the museum's reinstallation of its world-renowned holdings of ancient Egyptian art, this dazzling display rounds up more than 600 objects -- from king-and-queen-size monuments to tiny rings and amulets -- from the predynastic period to the 18th Dynasty. Together with the first phase, which opened in 1993 and covers later Egyptian art, visitors will now be able to trace the entire course of this brilliant and complex civilization from its beginnings to its absorption by the Roman Empire in 30 B.C. The heart of the new installation is an introductory gallery that provides a wonderful summation, with a survey of sculptural styles and displays of weapons, pottery, cosmetics, jewelry, furniture and funerary arts. The adjacent galleries are devoted to an extensive chronological survey. Hours: Wednesdays through Fridays, 10 a.m. to 5 p.m.; Saturdays and Sundays, 11 a.m. to 6 p.m. (until 11 p.m. the first Saturday of each month). Admission: $6;$3 for students and 62+ (Grace Glueck).

* "MANET/VELAZQUEZ: THE FRENCH TASTE FOR SPANISH PAINTING," Metropolitan Museum of Art, Fifth Avenue and 82nd Street, (212) 535-7710 (through June 8). The Met has clearly called in every chip to make this show spectacular. The first rooms are a virtual survey of great Spanish painting of the 17th and 18th centuries; after that comes a virtual Manet retrospective, with some Degas and Courbet thrown in for good measure; then a virtual 19th-century American overview of the most gifted portraitists influenced by Spanish painting via Manet, Degas and Courbet: Eakins, Chase, Sargent and Whistler. The thesis of Spanish influence on French art is hardly new, but it is explored in such precise and fresh detail, discreetly, without pushing comparisons (in that respect it's not like "Matisse Picasso" at the Modern, notwithstanding the coincidental titled pairings) that you would have to be churlish not to leave edified and amazed. Hours: Sundays and Tuesdays through Thursdays, 9:30 a.m. to 5:30 p.m.; Fridays and Saturdays until 9 p.m. Admission: $12; $7 for students and 65+ (Kimmelman).

* "MATISSE PICASSO," Museum of Modern Art, Queens, 4520 33rd Street, at Queens Boulevard, Long Island City, (212) 708-9400 (through May 19). If you're thinking of skipping it because of the crowds, that's not a good enough excuse. This is one for the ages: an eye-educating, often revelatory parlor game, with the fate of modern art as the stakes. The premise is a little dubious -- the two of them competing as if in stately isolation from everything else going on in art -- but the results look great. Choosing a winner is the sport of the event and the inevitable outcome of pitting titans mano a mano. Matisse comes out looking consistently good. To grasp 20th-century art, Picasso once said, "you ought to see side by side everything Matisse and I were doing." He was right about that. Hours: Thursdays through Mondays, 10 a.m. to 5 p.m; to 9 p.m. on Fridays and Saturdays. Admission: $20; $15.50, students and 65+; under 16 with an adult, free. Reserved tickets: Ticketmaster, (212) 307-5577; or toll free, (866) 879-6662, with Ticketmaster surcharges (Kimmelman).

"ELIE NADELMAN: SCULPTOR OF MODERN LIFE," Whitney Museum of American Art, 945 Madison Avenue, at 75th Street, (212) 570-3600 (through July 20). Despite the clarion title, this exhibition is too monotonous, stiffly installed and short on drawings to do full justice to the erudite, polymorphous achievement of the Polish-born American sculptor Nadelman (1882-1946). Still, don't miss this opportunity to see his work in quantity, especially the streamlined wood figures from the 1920's and the small truculent plaster figurines, which were found in his studio after his death. Their suave economy, ineffable stillness, delicate gestures and seamless blend of historical and popular sources make them among the most complex, fully visual sculptures in Western art. Hours: Tuesdays through Thursdays, Saturdays and Sundays, 11 a.m. to 6 p.m.; Fridays, 1 to 9 p.m. Admission: $12; $9.50, students and 62+ (Roberta Smith).

* "ST. ADOLF-GIANT-CREATION: THE ART OF ADOLF WOLFLI," American Folk Art Museum, 45 West 53rd Street, (212) 265-1040 (through May 18). The distinction between insider and outsider art is all but nullified by this stunning show of the densely patterned drawings that Wolfli (1864-1930) made in the last 35 years of his life at Waldau, a mental asylum in Bern, Switzerland. Brought to order by vast architectonic structures that allow several forms of communication to speak at once yet remain distinct, these works are embedded with saints, devils, written texts, mathematical calculations, musical scores and geometric symbols. They treat the eye to a ride through a multicultural terrain bounded by Piranesi, biblical myth, illuminated manuscripts, tantric mandalas and Swiss cuckoo clocks. And they attest to a vision as ancient as it is modern that verifies both Wolfli's careful observation of his surroundings and Jung's theory of the collective unconscious. Not to be missed. Hours: Tuesdays through Sundays, 10 a.m. to 6 p.m.; Fridays, 10 a.m. to 8 p.m. Admission: $9; $5, students and 62+ (Smith).

* "CHRISTIAN SCHAD AND THE NEUE SACHLICHKEIT," Neue Galerie, 1048 Fifth Avenue, at 86th Street, (212) 628-6200 (through June 9). Schad's career effectively lasted only 15 years, from around 1915 to 1930, and for just two or three of those years was he doing what deserves to be remembered now. Not much time. But just enough. Schad at his mordant best precisely captured an anxious culture affected by war and the threat of it: his bloodless portraits in Vienna and Berlin suggest deep unease and foreboding beneath porcelain surfaces. They are explicitly unemotional, even when they are frankly erotic, as they frequently are. His drawing, akin to some done by Dix and Grosz, shy away from the issues of class conflict that inflamed both of those other artists. To the end, Schad remained aloof. Hours: Fridays, 11 a.m. to 9 p.m.; Saturdays, Sundays and Mondays, 11 a.m. to 6 p.m. Admission: $10; $7 for students and 65+
(Kimmelman).

* "THOMAS STRUTH, 1977-2002," Metropolitan Museum of Art, Fifth Avenue and 82nd Street, (212) 535-7710 (through May 18). This midcareer retrospective is the right event for right now: serious, traditionbound, circumspect about the world. Mr. Struth operates from a chilly peak, where the air is thin. But what results are obsessively meticulous photographs, some of them enormous, like mural paintings. They are hypnotic, silent, slightly claustrophobic, brainy and gorgeous, qualities that can seem in lively tension with one another. Art is a means of "locating yourself in your time," Mr. Struth has said. He has done series of streets, jungles, museums, portraits and church facades. Standing before his crowded museums and churches, we can become absorbed in the chaos of culture, sacred places made profane. In the jungle we acquiesce to the spiritual pleasure of solitude. We may find ourselves in our time. Hours and admission: See above (Kimmelman).

* "TRANSMITTING THE FORMS OF DIVINITY: EARLY BUDDHIST ART FROM KOREA AND JAPAN," Japan Society, 333 East 47th Street, (212) 832-1155 (through June 22). The role of Korea in the development of Buddhist art and thought in Japan, and therefore in the formation of Japanese culture itself, emerges from decades of habitual marginalization in this beautiful exhibition. Dominated by meditating Buddhas and handsomely attired bodhisattvas dating from the sixth to the ninth centuries, the show, which has been organized with the Korea Society of New York, dispenses lessons in several kinds of grace, religious as well as formal. It highlights the forceful stylization and subtle abstraction of the human figure, which while common in Asian and African art, is rarely equaled in Western sculpture between the medieval and modern periods. Hours: Tuesdays through Fridays, 11 a.m. to 6 p.m.; Saturdays and Sundays, 11 a.m. to 5 p.m. Admission: $5; $3, students and 65+ (Smith).

"VIETNAM: JOURNEYS OF BODY, MIND AND SPIRIT," American Museum of Natural History, Central Park West at 79th Street, (212) 769-5100 (through Jan. 4). For many Americans who came of age before or during the 1960's, Vietnam was the name of a place you didn't want to go. Even today the prevailing impression of this part of Southeast Asia seems to be a composite of remembered news clips and scenes from "Apocalypse Now." More than a quarter-century after the war, the image is due for revision, and that is the basic idea behind this show, a lavishly illustrated anthropological field trip through Vietnam today. Using objects, videos and photographs it examines popular traditions associated with marriage, death and religion, often to vivid effect, in a lively, serpentine installation. And even with many important political and social questions left unasked and unanswered, there is a wealth of information here. Hours: Daily, 10 a.m. to 5:45 p.m. Admission: $12; $9, students and 60+ (Holland Cotter).

Galleries: Uptown

* "SEEING RED I: PIONEERS OF NONOBJECTIVE PAINTING," Hunter College Art Galleries, 68th Street and Lexington Avenue, (212) 772-4991 (through May 3). The optical and symbolic power of red is the basis of this one-color show, which presents a lineup of wonderful paintings, beginning with work by two significant emigre painter-teachers, Hans Hofmann and Josef Albers. The focus on one color affords a more intense observation of differences in surface and texture, subtle gradations in tone and the play of light. Besides the controlled geometrics of Albers's nested boxes and the dynamic Expressionist splash of Hofmann's fiery painted ball, there are works by Jack Youngerman, Tony Smith, Richard Anuszkiewicz, Richard Pousette-Dart, Kenneth Noland and Robert Motherwell, among others (Glueck).

* "KURT SCHWITTERS: COLLAGES, PAINTINGS, DRAWINGS, OBJECTS, EPHEMERA," Ubu Gallery, 416 East 59th Street, (212) 753-4444 (through May 23). The German artist Kurt Schwitters (1887-1948) made artful arrangements of found scraps -- torn photographs, ticket stubs, labels, newspaper clips and other discarded bits -- into abstract compositions that balanced colors, forms, textures and printed matter to dazzling effect. More than 60 of his works, Dada-oriented but also much influenced by Constructivism and Russian Suprematism, are brought together here in a museum-quality display that ranges in date from before 1920 to the late 1940's. One standout in this bountiful show is a gem from 1931, "Untitled (Red, Gray, Black)," a rigorously structured composition with all the elegant trappings of Suprematism-Constructivism brilliantly translated into "Merz," Schwitters's no-meaning name for his own visual language (Glueck).

* "WEAVING CHINA'S PAST: THE AMY S. CLAUGUE COLLECTION OF CHINESE TEXTILES," China Institute Gallery, 125 East 65th Street, (212) 744-8181 (through June 7). This gallery has a sterling record in presenting small, fine-tuned scholarly shows and this one, imported from the Phoenix Art Museum, exactly fits the description. With precious examples of silk brocades, tapestries and embroideries, including Buddhist ritual pieces, dating from the Jin to Qing dynasty, it gives a vivid sense of the material past in a powerful imperial culture (Cotter).

Galleries: 57th Street

JOHN CEDERQUIST, "Furniture That Builds Itself," Franklin Parrasch, 20 West 57th Street, (212) 246-5360 (through May 31). Mr. Cederquist's beautifully made woodworks are simultaneously functional pieces of furniture and zany cartoons in two and three dimensions. With painted Mickey Mouse arms wielding drills and planes as if in the act of building, these funky sculptures are deceptively whimsical meditations on the mind's construction of reality (Ken Johnson).

VIJA CELMINS, Susan Sheehan, 20 West 57th Street, (212) 489-3331 (through May 31). Unlike the many painters and sculptors for whom printmaking is a more or less casual diversion, Ms. Celmins invests as much painstaking concentration in it as she does in her paintings. This selection from three decades includes misty etchings of spider webs, rippling waters made in lithography and wood engraving, mezzotinted starry night skies and lithographs of desert fields (Johnson).

LYNN DAVIS, "China," Edwynn Houk, 745 Fifth Avenue, (212) 750-7070 (through May 3). A photographer known for her spectacular pictures of icebergs and Egyptian pyramids, takes on China. Towering pagodas, a giant Buddha in a cave, ancient stairs partly submerged in sand, a beautiful minaret with a surface of intricate brickwork: these and other subjects are rendered in large, smooth black-and-white prints. Her relentless monumentalism can make you wonder whether Ms. Davis has a more intimate side (Johnson).

EMILY EVELETH, Danese, 41 East 57th Street, (212) 223-2227 (through May 10). With a soft painterly touch, Ms. Evelth turns humble jelly doughnuts into a monumental, voluptuous objects of desire. Glowing and looming against dark backgrounds singly or in piled groups, they laze like corpulent odalisques. Each has its dark, raspberry-stained orifice turned to the viewer, to slightly alarming effect (Johnson).

Galleries: Chelsea

FERNANDO BERMEJO, "Lights," Generous Miracles, 529 West 20th Street, (212) 352-2858 (through May 13). The light box is popular with photographers but rarely used to illuminate handmade pictures. Black-and-white paintings on paper mounted on light boxes by this Spanish artist suggest possibilities worth exploring. Lighted from behind, his small, brushy pastoral landscapes have a remarkable naturalistic luminosity and his surrealistic visions of trees growing from small boats have a dusky, melancholy poetry (Johnson).

ALEXANDER CALDER, Van de Weghe, 521 West 23rd Street, (212) 929-6633 (through May 23). This sampler includes a huge mobile that is too big for the gallery's main room and a bright red nonmoving abstraction of a winged lion. Best are the smaller mobiles, some hung from the ceiling, some balanced on low structures on the floor. These harmoniously choreographed, Miroesque constellations of sweeping lines and biomorphic shapes might be Platonic models for an ecology of mind and soul (Johnson).

LINDA FLEMING, "Parallel Universe," Linda Durham, 210 11th Avenue, (212) 337-0025 (through May 8). Ms. Fleming, a California sculptor, develops complex patterns of layered and interwoven bands that are meant to have metaphysical implications. Whatever they mean, a large, intricate, fanlike structure of bolted-together rusted steel parts; a shadow of that sculpture made of puzzled-together black rubber pieces, lying flat on the floor; and a balsa-wood maquette under a glass bubble all have considerable terrestrial presence (Johnson).

JEAN-FRANCOIS MORICEAU AND PETRA MRZYK, "Only for Your Eyes," Marcus Ritter, 453 West 17th Street, (212) 463-7375 (through May 17). This young cartoon-making team generates sight gags with seemingly effortless abandon. Hairy prehistoric people shaving their private parts; anthropomorphic paintings on strike, carrying signs that say, "We want a new curator"; an owl with Mickey Mouse ears; a woman with square breasts; a giant eye with two pupils. More than 100 of these black-ink line drawings, individually framed and stacked up against the wall, will give your sense of humor an invigorating workout (Johnson).

"SUNDAY PAINTERS: DISCARDED PAINTINGS BY GIFTED AMATEURS," Ricco/Maresca, 529 West 20th Street, (212) 627-4819 (through May 3). Among this exhibition's assorted paintings by unknown amateurs are works of comical ineptitude, off-beat invention and nutty, perverse or ridiculously banal imagery. The show's best painting is "Maine Couple," an unsigned double portrait from the 1950's. It was copied, apparently, from a snapshot but its precise formality calls to mind the great early American folk artist Ammi Phillips (Johnson).

BETTY WOODMAN: "Souvenirs," Max Protech, 511 West 22nd Street, (212) 633-6999 (through May 3). Recent travels in Europe, India and East Asia have given the ceramist Betty Woodman, an inventive vessel maker, some engaging ideas that build on a long Woodman-esque tradition -- for example, lively miniature stage sets whose crisply delineated actors are vessels and shards in Matisse-style cutout shapes. They were derived from the archaeology of the Aeolian Islands off Sicily. A visit to Asia and the sight of sculptures of deities clad in fabric inspired her to make a group of vases dressed in brightly colored robes and echoing womanly shapes. There are many more delights in this animated show (Glueck).

Galleries: SoHo

"EXTRA," Swiss Institute, 495 Broadway, near Spring Street, (212) 925-2035 (through May 10). The curator Marc-Olivier Wahler asks, "How many extra layers can we graft onto reality before it collapses?" The 11 works here do little to answer the question, but they make an entertaining show. They include Bruno Peinado's giant brown Michelin man with an Afro; Wim Delvoye's tattooed pig; Peter Fischli and David Weiss's trompe-l'oeil studio props; Olivier Blanckart's Village People made of paper and tape; and adorable little robotic dogs programmed to fight by Stephane Sautour (Johnson).

HEIDE FASNACHT, Kent, 67 Prince Street, (212) 966-4500 (through May 3). A sculptor known for her interest in explosions offers a bursting Champagne bottle and splashy puddles, both in cast blue resin, and a sneeze represented by perforations in paper. A big colored pencil drawing of a window glass washed by rain, made with crisp gray and blue hatchmarks, reveals on close inspection an absorbing, crystalline topography; from a distance it resolves into a magically luminous illusion of watery translucency (Johnson).

GEORGE McNEIL, "FE = Form/Energy," Luise Ross, 568 Broadway, at Prince Street, (212) 343-2161 (through May 3). McNeil, who died in 1995 an underrecognized member of the Abstract Expressionist generation, merged painterly abstraction and primitivistic symbolism with sensuous buoyancy. This small selection of works from four decades includes colorful, transcendentally exuberant landscapes and pictures of scary masklike faces embedded in luxuriantly scabrous surfaces (Johnson).

"MADONNA AND STEVEN KLEIN: X-STATIC PRO=CESS." Deitch Projects, 18 Wooster Street, near Grand Street, (212) 343-7300 (through May 3). Mr. Klein's tacky mural-sized photographs of the rock diva Madonna in various histrionic ensembles and sets might as well be stills from unusually egregious music videos, except that they occasionally twitch. Their blatant derivativeness can make you momentarily giddy with something resembling delight (Smith).

* "THE STAGE OF DRAWING: GESTURE AND ACT," Drawing Center, 35 Wooster Street, (212) 219-2166 (through May 31). It's not easy to assemble a truly engaging show from a vast collection of drawings like that owned by England's Tate. But this one, selected by a British artist, Avis Newman, with Catherine de Zegher, director of the Drawing Center, really works. Not a tiresome institutional tour but a vividly personal one, it views drawing as "an open-ended and exploratory activity," with exhibits ranging from a 295-foot line on a roll of wrapped paper to precise renderings of 19th-century hairdos. The mix of artists runs from J. M. W. Turner to Andy Warhol; the juxtapositions reveal affinities across centuries and cultures (Glueck).

Other Galleries

* TARA DONOVAN, Ace Gallery, 276 Hudson Street, South Village, (212) 255-5599 (through May 15). Installation art proved long ago that lots of space combined with lots and lots of one material, arranged by stupefyingly simple labor-intensive methods, can work wonders. This solo debut provides supporting evidence that, if not too original, is amazingly succinct. The materials include transparent tape, Elmer's glue and pencils; the high point is something that looks, from afar, like a fairly large cloud or snow bank, but is not (Smith).

ANN SPERRY, "30 Pieces/30 Years," Hebrew Union College-Jewish Institute of Religion Museum, 1 West Fourth Street, Greenwich Village, (212) 824-2205 (through June 26); "My Piano," Kraushaar, 724 Fifth Avenue, at 57th Street, (212) 307-5730 (through April 12). Since the early 1970's, Ms. Sperry has been bending, shaping and welding metal into metaphorically suggestive abstractions. The best works in her Hebrew Union retrospective have an industrial surrealism similar to, though not as surprising as, that of Donald Lipski. Her new assemblages at Kraushaar include cutup parts of her old piano, a beloved but defunct family heirloom (Johnson).

Brooklyn

ROBERT GRUNDER, Sixtyseven, 67 Metropolitan Avenue, Williamsburg, Brooklyn, (718) 486-0387 (through May 18). Mr. Grunder's semi-abstract paintings of mall stores and parking lots are O.K., but his bird's-eye views of freeways, overpasses and cloverleaf intersections painted on white grounds have a cool dynamism that nicely evokes the speediness of modern life (Johnson).

SCOTT TEPLIN, "Moron," Jessica Murray Projects, 210 North Sixth Street, Williamsburg, Brooklyn, (718) 384-9606 (through May 11). Mr. Teplin's delightfully inventive drawing is like a conference call among Dr. Seuss, R. Crumb, Ed Ruscha and Rube Goldberg. Words like moron, flap jack and bonus hole are dug into the ground, constructed from industrial steel or whirling in space, while floating beds, gobs of mud, circulating tubes, spurting, gnarly nipples and disembodied mouths convey a spirit of gleeful surrender to the mind's own perversely polymorphous energies (Johnson).

Last Chance

* VALERIE JAUDON, Von Lintel, 555 West 25th Street, Chelsea, (212) 242-0599 (through tomorrow). If there were such a thing as modern Sufi painting, it might look like Ms. Jaudon's work. Five gorgeous new pictures extend her two-decade involvement in Middle Eastern flavored patterning. With their luscious, confectionery colors and luminous glazes -- flaming hot in some, sherbet cool in others -- they are sensuously seductive and transcendentally inspiring (Johnson).

* BILL JENSEN, Mary Boone, 745 Fifth Avenue, at 57th Street, (212) 752-2929 (through tomorrow). Where once it was biomorphic-bristly, Mr. Jensen's compositions seem to have mellowed over the years into softer, less defined forms, his surfaces more grounds for colors than for shapes. The forms in these latest works are really markings, sprawly scrawls and calligraphic gestures that play splashily over contrasting close-valued grounds, sometimes to gorgeous effect. The star of the show is "Untitled (Ocher and Red)," in which a more definite form, that of a red partial cross, occupies the top half of a glowing field brushed thinly enough to show glints of red beneath it. Harking back to medieval and Byzantine sources, it is a mini-cathedral (Glueck).

* AGNES MARTIN, "Five Decades," Zwirner & Wirth, 32 East 69th Street, (212) 517-8677 (through tomorrow). We're used to expecting nuances rather than revolutions in Ms. Martin's art. But this 10-painting capsule survey gives a sense of how varied she can be and has been. It also proves how right she is in referring to herself as an Abstract Expressionist when everyone else has been calling her a Minimalist all these years. She's an engaged, passionate gestural painter with a classicist's emotional tact, a reticent Abstract Expressionist, the way Philip Guston was (Cotter).

* ELIZABETH MURRAY, PaceWildenstein, 534 West 25th Street, Chelsea, (212) 929-7000 (through tomorrow). A life lived the way Ms. Murray paints would be nirvana. Her recent works are airy constructions in low relief:
ad hoc jigsaw puzzles of freewheeling shapes that lean, nuzzle and jostle one another to make unlikely harmonies of pungent color and abstract pattern. Compositional equilibrium, laboriously achieved but seemingly effortless, looks fleeting: there's always the sense that these improvisatory jumbles might break apart and out of their frames. Ms. Murray loves to paint. That's still the bottom line. It is useful to be reminded that there are still veterans like her, steeped in the medium, its difficulties and pleasures, who work so hard and make such beautiful art (Kimmelman).

HELEN TORR, "Works on Paper," JG Contemporary, 505 West 28th Street, Chelsea, (212) 564-7662 (through tomorrow). Torr, who was married to Arthur Dove, was a fine painter in her own right. The influence of Dove, Hartley, Burchfield and other American Modernists are evident in her work, but she had her own lively and intimate personality. It is stunning to learn that she never sold a painting in her lifetime, having subordinated her own career to her husband's. This engaging small show of drawings anticipates a retrospective of paintings scheduled for next month a JG Contemporary's uptown gallery (Johnson).

* "VIDEO ACTS: SINGLE CHANNEL WORKS FROM THE COLLECTIONS OF PAMELA AND RICHARD KRAMLICH AND NEW ART TRUST," P.S. 1 Contemporary Art Center, 22-25 Jackson Avenue, at 46th Street, Long Island City, Queens, (718) 784-2084 (through Monday). Wading through this sprawling survey of early single-channel video art is more edifying than enjoyable, but anyone interested in contemporary art should make the effort. Expertly installed with viewing efficiency in mind, it concentrates on works made mostly by lone artists experimenting behind closed studio doors in the 1970's. A handful of recent videotapes by Pipilotti Rist and others underscores the feeling that both the medium and its early pioneers have come a long way. Hours: Thursdays through Mondays, noon to 6 p.m. Admission: $5; $2 for students and 62+ (Smith).

GRAPHIC: Photos: Last Chance: Bill Jensen's "Untitled (Ocher and Red)" at Boone. (Mary Boone Gallery); "Dancer" is part of an Elie Nadelman retrospective at the Whitney. (Whitney Museum of American Art)

HEADLINE: HAVENS; 
Is the Party Over For Summer Shares In the Hamptons?

BYLINE:  By WALECIA KONRAD

 BODY:
IT was a police operation worthy of prime-time TV. A half-dozen officers armed with search warrants stormed into a six-bedroom house on Laura Court in the Southampton, N.Y., hamlet of East Quogue at 6 a.m. on a Sunday last August. The 30 or so people inside, all in their 20's or 30's, were rousted from mattresses strewn throughout the house. According to people who were there, bleary-eyed young men stumbled out onto the front lawn and wincedin the daylight. 
 First the Conscience Point Inn, a favorite eastern Long Island reveling spot, is shuttered, and now this. The long tradition of dozens of young people crowding into a Hamptons house for a summer of wild abandon is under attack. A rush of activity last year in East Quogue -- neighborhood spying, morning police raids and, perhaps most effective, authorities' use of a television documentary by Barbara Kopple to identify offenders -- has led to a crackdown on Hamptons share houses this year. 
 The Town Board of Southampton, which shut down six houses last year in East Quogue, has tougher penalties ready for housing code violators this year, and other Hamptons towns and villages are greeting the new season with beefed-up inspection squads and stricter rules. 
The crackdown is hardly the death of summer shares. There are still plenty of classifieds in the back of The Village Voice and New York magazine hawking shares, and a recent Google search for "Hamptons group homes" yielded dozens of Web advertisements. But local laws typically cap the allowable number of unrelated adults living in a house at well under a dozen, and active enforcement could put a further crimp in a party scene already subdued by an uncertain economy.
"The market is definitely much slower this year," said Cass Almendral, a homeowner in Southampton village who has sold shares in his house in the past. At a recent party in Manhattan at which owners of six share houses were recruiting renters, he said, "only about 40 people showed up." In the past, he added, "you'd see 300 people at an event like that." Some potential renters are also turned off by the problems with group houses last year. "It's definitely something people are worried about," Mr. Almendral said. 
Controversy about share houses is not new, but it took on new life a year ago when Sandeep and Nina Dmietrieff Mehta bought a weekend house on Jeffrey Lane, a street perpendicular to Laura Court in an isolated wooded area just south of the Sunrise Highway. The neighborhood is deceptively peaceful in April, the month the Mehtas moved in. But it is filled with six- and seven-bedroom houses with pools, hot tubs and tennis and basketball courts. Many are owned by investors or out-of-state residents who hire young house managers to recruit potential renters and take care of things during the summer.
"Everyone knows that area is notorious for professional group homes," said Richard Casabianca, chairman of the Citizens Advisory Committee, a volunteer community group in nearby Hampton Bays. "But they were so isolated that no one was really bothered by it."
No one, it seems, except the Mehtas. By Memorial Day, a neighbor said, the Mehtas realized that their weekend retreat felt like a frat house thanks to the late-night parties, noise and frequently crass behavior at houses on either side.
The Mehtas complained to the Town Board, but the most officials could do at first was issue parking tickets or write citations for noise violations. The partying continued.
The Mehtas soon found allies. Lydia Staiano, an East Quogue resident and member of the Citizens Advisory Committee, and the committee chairwoman, Elizabeth Haderer, had long been concerned about share houses and worried that neighbors might be too intimidated to complain. Now, with the help of the Mehtas and Ms. Haderer, Ms. Staiano set out to collect enough evidence for the town to get a search warrant.
On Saturday nights, when the deck parties near the Mehtas' house were in full swing, Ms. Staiano would show up and take notes. "The music would just be blasting from the deck next door," she said. "Cars would be parked everywhere, blocking neighbors' driveways. Any given weekend night there would be dozens of people drinking out on the deck." What is more, she said, people from the group houses were in continual motion back and forth between parties. "These kids were constantly trampling over the couple's lawn, urinating, yelling, what have you," she said. 
Then, Sunday morning, while the revelers were sleeping, Ms. Staiano would arrive, Polaroid in hand, to document the party aftermath at the various group houses. "It was a nightmare," she said. "Whole garbage cans of beer bottles were dumped on the lawns, garbage was everywhere."
Inside houses like the ones in East Quogue, more chaos reigned. Daisy Sosa, a 26-year-old graduate student, bought a share in a group house in Hampton Bays last year with a group of 15 friends and friends of friends. "We had four bedrooms, each with four or five people, and two bathrooms," she said. "That was O.K., but it didn't take long for everyone to start bringing their friends out. At one point we had six guys sleeping in the basement. You never knew from one weekend to the next who was going to be there. I was in the kitchen one morning and this guy comes upstairs and says, 'Can you drive me to Turtle Bay?' I said, 'Excuse me, do I know you?' "
Meanwhile, at the town hall, officials were dealing with complaints from the Mehtas and some of their newly emboldened neighbors, as well as Ms. Staiano's Polaroids and her handwritten logs of infractions. Ms. Staiano also gave officials a videotape of the ABC program "The Hamptons" by Barbara Kopple that had been broadcast in June. One of the prominent characters in it was Josh Sagman, a part-owner of the group house next door to the Mehtas. In addition to showing a close-up of the giant pulsating outdoor speakers, the film had recorded Mr. Sagman presiding over crowded parties on the deck of the house and at hot spots like Conscience Point, the club where Elizabeth S. Grubman, a New York publicist, had backed an S.U.V. into a crowd in the summer of 2001. During one of the deck party scenes, a bunch of young men were shown lifting another man upside down while he chugged from the spout of a keg of beer. 
"I made every effort to be a good neighbor," Mr. Sagman said in an interview this week. "Remember, those scenes in the documentary were filmed the year before. As soon as Memorial Day, when I knew the new neighbors were concerned about our house, I made sure we kept quiet and I personally made sure all of the trash was picked up each morning. Most of the photographs the neighbors took weren't from my house. But because the documentary showed me as some kind of super partier instead of a person, I became the poster child for share houses in the Hamptons."
A strong part of the case against share houses developed last summer when someone in town noticed that a group house was advertising a Fourth of July party on the Internet for $15 a head, a violation of the Southampton town code that prohibits operating a business on residential premises. So many people showed up at the party -- more than 3,000, town officials estimated -- that the police barricaded Laura Court to stop any more from coming. "That party was the finishing straw," said Eileen Powers, acting town attorney. "Right after that we executed the search warrants."
In each of several houses on Jeffrey Lane and Laura Court, inspectors found as many as 20 housing code violations. In some houses it was wall-to-wall beds. "We even found beds near the furnace," Ms. Powers said, "and that's a fire hazard." The six houses that the town ordered vacated included the one run by Josh Sagman next door to the Mehtas.
It was apparently too late for the Mehtas, who sold their house last October. Attempts to contact them for comment were unsuccessful. (Mr. Sagman and his partners have also sold their house.) But year-round Southampton residents kept up the pressure, and the Town Board increased the penalties for having more than five unrelated adults living under one roof to $1,000 a day from $250 a day. "That's enough to be meaningful," Ms. Powers said. "Before, the owners just figured the fines were part of the cost of doing business."
Other Hamptons officials have taken up the cause. Thomas Lawrence, a code enforcement officer for the Village of East Hampton, said the village had added a third code enforcement officer in preparation for the coming season. And the Town of East Hampton, which governs part of Sag Harbor, Wainscott, Amagansett, the Springs and Montauk, has a new rule requiring 75 square feet of sleeping space for one person and 50 square feet each if two share a room.
The new rules and enforcement on Hamptons share houses also apply to rental properties overcrowded with waiters, landscapers and other laborers -- people whose services are needed in the Hamptons but whose housing needs are largely unmet.
Of course this problem isn't unique to the Hamptons. Ocean Bay Park and Kismet on Fire Island and Spring Lake on the Jersey Shore are among many other towns known for packed share houses despite local laws that restrict the number of occupants. Grace Corradino, owner of Fire Island Living, a real estate company, said, "Until the neighborhood changes or someone complains, group homes are a fact of life."
Some activists worry that the crackdown in the Hamptons will not go far enough. "There's been a tolerance of share houses on the part of town officials for years," said Mr. Casabianca of Hampton Bays. "The problem won't be solved until the people who come out to these houses get the message that renting a summer share in the Hamptons is not a license to be a jerk."
On the flip side, some homeowners say the crackdown is misguided and ill-timed. "It's unconstitutional to tell people they can't rent their homes, whether it's to a group or not," said Don MacPherson, the publisher of SoHo Journal and a former investor in share houses in the Hamptons. "And in this economy this could be the nail in the coffin for the summer rental market."
And Mr. Almendral said he and about 25 other homeowners were researching the possibility of a class-action suit against the Town of Southampton, charging that the laws discriminate against single people.
For their part, local officials contend that they walk a fine line between the private business of owners renting their properties and the public nuisances that some houses become. The Town of Southampton, Ms. Powers said, wants to make it clear that if group houses make problems for their neighbors, they can expect enforcement. But at the same time, she said, "We don't want to ruin anyone's summer."

GRAPHIC: Photos: PARTY HOUSE -- In a scene, above, from "The Hamptons," a documentary film, Josh Sagman, rear right, shared a hot tub in the summer of 2001 at his East Quogue, N.Y., house. Right, at the same house, a man drank beer from a keg while upside down. (pg. F8) Drawing (Nancy Carpenter)(pg. F1)

HEADLINE: FILM REVIEW; 
Fathers, Sons, Grandsons, In the Script and Real Life

BYLINE:  By STEPHEN HOLDEN 

 BODY:
Fiction and reality are so seamlessly blended in "It Runs in the Family," a surprisingly complex and subtle portrait of the Grombergs, a high-powered clan of New York lawyers, that the temptation to assume its characters are modeled after the actors playing them is almost irresistible. Four of those actors -- Kirk, Michael, Cameron and Diana Douglas -- are related by birth or by marriage and play fictionalized versions of themselves in the film.
 Throughout the movie you can feel the actors' offscreen relationships resonating with their performances and enriching them immeasurably. One strand of a story that deftly skips among half a dozen major characters is the strained but loving relationship of the Grombergs' cantankerous patriarch, Mitchell (Kirk Douglas), and Alex (Michael Douglas), his son, who works in the New York law firm his father founded. The two stars have made no secret that their relationship has weathered its share of strife. In the case of the Grombergs, Alex continually grumbles that his hard-bitten father, a feisty, scowling World War II veteran recovering from a stroke (despite a speech impediment, he has "a few good years left," Mitchell's doctor assures him), has never demonstrated his approval or declared his love. 
 The movie, which opens nationwide today, is wonderful at showing how trivial incidents can unlock reserves of festering resentment in a high-strung household whose male members are infused with the same hyper-competitive success ethic that echoes what we know about the Kennedys. Michael's son Cameron makes a splashy acting debut as 21-year-old Asher, the older of Alex's two sons. An arrogant, girl-crazy part-time D.J. with a macho hip-hop attitude, Asher, who is failing in school, deals homegrown marijuana. And his 11-year-old brother, Eli (Rory Culkin), a brash martial-arts whiz, appears to be on the same reckless path.
The scenes of three generations of Bromberg males bumping elbows depict a lineage in which the testosterone runs rampant. Mitchell, who is somewhere in his 80's, is still a dogged fighter who takes (slow) daily jogs around the Central Park Reservoir. Alex, although happily married to Rebecca (Bernadette Peters), a psychotherapist, is helpless to resist when Suzie (Sarita Choudhury), a young assistant in the soup kitchen where he volunteers, furiously flings herself at him and refuses to take no for an answer. (This scene amusingly parodies the star's moments of sex-under-siege in "Fatal Attraction" and "Disclosure.")
Lastly, there is Diana Douglas (Michael's real-life mother and former wife of Kirk) as Evelyn, Alex's mother and Mitchell's devoted spouse, a super-competent matriarch and caretaker. Like her son, Evelyn has suffered from Mitchell's benign emotional neglect (although her husband is completely dependent on her).
Because "It Runs in the Family" is so steeped in Hollywood tradition, you keep expecting the usual feel-good formulas of serious domestic comedy to kick in and hijack the movie by turning it into an innocuous sugarcoated placebo. But, wonder of wonders, it doesn't happen. Before the film is over, two of the major characters have died and been mourned. And although the Grombergs' interlocking personal dramas ultimately bring them somewhat closer, the screenplay offers no pat resolutions to any of their problems. The movie gazes as steadily at the decrepitude of old age as it does at the chutzpah of youthful entitlement. Nor does it shy away from the Grombergs' Jewishness, which is central to their identity.
Alex's wandering eye gets him exiled from the bedroom, while his social conscience seriously collides with the financial interests of his law firm. Mitchell, browbeaten by his wife and son to be more expressive, rails against old age. Asher's drug dealing catches up with him just as he is about to embark on his first serious relationship. Eli develops a crush on a runaway girl with a pierced nose.
Although these and other subplots create a much more complex narrative framework than most filmmakers would dream of constructing, Jesse Wigutow's screenplay is one of those marvels of economy, idiomatic facility and well-chosen detail that knows exactly when to cut away from a scene without grinding it into your face. And Fred Schepisi's direction finds a comfortable balance between comedy and clear-eyed realism. Over and over, the movie flirts with sentimentality, then dances away from it. Its only serious lapses into mush are the scenes of Evelyn coaxing Mitchell into dancing to Bobby Darin's recording of "You'll Never Know," which turns into the movie's maudlin and redundant theme song.
Besides its laudable reluctance to tie up loose ends, the most courageous thing about "It Runs in the Family" is its refusal to try to make you love its aggressive, strong-willed characters. Alex may be a good guy (he volunteers at a soup kitchen and does pro bono work for worthy causes), but like his father, he is a bully. So is the obnoxious but charismatic Asher. Although the movie may not be aware of its message, it portrays the cost of certain kinds of professional success as an inability to let go, relax and smell the roses. It's that inability that keeps the Grombergs, despite their talents and their social conscience, from being particularly likable people.
"It Runs in the Family" is rated PG-13 (Parents strongly cautioned). It has strong language and sexual situations.

IT RUNS IN THE FAMILY

Directed by Fred Schepisi; written by Jesse Wigutow; director of photography, Ian Baker; edited by Kate Williams; music by Paul Grabowsky; production designer, Patrizia Von Brandenstein; produced by Michael Douglas; released by Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer Pictures and Buena Vista International. Running time: 109 minutes. This film is rated PG-13.

WITH: Michael Douglas (Alex Gromberg), Kirk Douglas (Mitchell Gromberg), Rory Culkin (Eli Gromberg), Cameron Douglas (Asher Gromberg), Diana Douglas (Evelyn Gromberg), Michelle Monaghan (Peg Maloney), Sarita Choudhury (Suzie) and Bernadette Peters (Rebecca Gromberg).

HEADLINE: INSIDE ART 

BYLINE:  By Carol Vogel 

 BODY:
The Morgan Goes on Hiatus
 After next weekend, there will be one fewer museum to visit in Manhattan, though the loss will be only temporary. The Morgan Library will close its doors until early 2006 for a $100 million expansion and renovation. 
 As a kind of goodbye present to visitors, the museum will waive its requested fee on May 3 and 4, when admission will be pay-as-you-wish. 
"It's goodwill," said Charles E. Pierce Jr., director of the Morgan. "We wanted to leave visitors with a positive feeling and give everyone a chance to come for one last time."
Given the current economy and the drop in attendance that museums all over the country have been experiencing since 9/11, some institutions, including the Whitney Museum of American Art and the Los Angeles County Museum of Art, have abandoned their expansion plans. But the Morgan is forging ahead with the Italian architect Renzo Piano's design for a new reading room; more gallery space; a larger, modernized auditorium; a more welcoming entrance; and better circulation inside. 
"I'm pleased that the board wishes to proceed with the project, because we couldn't do it without them," Mr. Pierce said. "So far we've raised about $68 million toward the $100 million of the building project. We now need to raise an additional $25 million for the endowment. So the overall project is really $125 million."
Finances aside, the Morgan has made sure that highlights from its collection will still be available to the public after it closes. It has organized two traveling exhibitions to raise money for its operating expenses and to let other parts of the country see some of its treasures. One show, "Illuminated Best Sellers: Books of Hours From the Morgan Library," will go first to the Kimbell Art Museum in Fort Worth from Oct. 12 through Jan. 18, 2004, and then to the J. Paul Getty Museum in Los Angeles from Oct. 18, 2005, through Jan. 8, 2006. The second, "Imagine: British Drawings and Watercolors, 1600-1900," which was at the Morgan in 1998, will go to the Taft Museum of Art in Cincinnati from May 14 through Aug. 15, 2004, and then to the Frick Art and Historical Center in Pittsburgh in late 2005. 
Closer to home, the museum has already lent some of its prized objects to the Metropolitan Museum. In November, several of the Morgan's medieval artworks went on view at the Met's Medieval Tapestry Hall, where they are to remain for at least two and a half years. In February, two sculptures from the Morgan went to the Met's Egyptian galleries.
When the Met opens "Art of the First Cities: The Third Millennium B.C. From the Mediterranean to the Indus" on May 8, the show will also include some loans from the Morgan. Among them will be a copper figure, placed in the foundation of a building, particularly a temple, to purify and sanctify the edifice. One such figure, depicting King Ur-Nammu, the first king of the Third Dynasty of Ur, shows him standing, holding his arms up. A basket containing mud to make bricks -- the image is of the king as builder -- is balanced on his head.
One department at the Met that has particularly benefited from the Morgan's recent loans is European paintings. In the first of the Met's Netherlandish galleries is a wall of seven portraits by Hans Memling. Three are from the Morgan.
"In putting these all together, it becomes a group that is unparalleled outside of Bruges," said Maryan Ainsworth, a curator in the Met's department of European painting and sculpture. The portraits span the artist's career, from his earliest works -- two panels from a triptych dated around 1470 -- to a portrait of an old man from around 1480 to 1490, Ms. Ainsworth said.
"Ordinarily the panels hung in a dark study of Mr. Morgan's -- few people saw them," she said. One of the Morgan's panels shows a benefactor with her patron, St. Anne. "In this context," she said, "the kneeling figures are seen as portraits."
Ms. Ainsworth added that the loans had inspired her to begin planning an exhibition focusing on Memling.

The First Seagram Sale
Tonight, Phillips, de Pury & Luxembourg, the struggling Chelsea-based auction house, will begin selling more than 700 photographs that once lined Seagram offices at the Seagram Building on Park Avenue and at 800 Third Avenue.
The entire collection, expected to fetch $1.4 million to $2.1 million, is being sold without a reserve (the secret minimum price mutually agreed upon by the seller and the auction house), which means that works will go to the highest bidders regardless of market values.
"We've found no-reserve sales tend to do extremely well," said Joshua Holdeman, head of Phillips's photography department. It was also the neatest way of dealing with the sale, Mr. Holdeman added, since Vivendi Universal, the now troubled French entertainment conglomerate that bought Seagram two years ago, needs to dispose of the collection and doesn't want to be left with unsold photographs.
The collection, put together in part by Phyllis Lambert, the daughter of Samuel Bronfman, the Seagram patriarch, spans the first 80 years of the 20th century and concentrates on American architecture and urban life.
The first sale will be devoted to 20th-century American photography. Highlights include Walker Evans's "Main Street, Saratoga Springs, N.Y." (1931), which is expected to sell for $40,000 to $60,000. Another, Louis Faurer's "Broadway Convertible, Times Square, New York" (1949), captures the spirit of postwar New York. It is expected to fetch $10,000 to $15,000.
Also at auction will be William Eggleston's "14 Pictures" (1971-74). This suite of photographs, estimated at $100,000 to $150,000, shows unsettling but seemingly ordinary scenes of Memphis suburbs without a single human subject.
Vivendi is selling more than just photographs. It chose Phillips to auction its photography collection but gave Christie's its more valuable modern art. Among the works for sale next month is Rothko's "Brown and Blacks in Reds" (1957), estimated at $6 million to $8 million.

At the New Museum
The New Museum of Contemporary Art in SoHo is growing, and not only in size. (In December it announced plans to build a 60,000-square-foot, $35 million building on an 8,000-square-foot parking lot at the Bowery and Prince Street.) It also keeps increasing its staff. 
This week it announced the appointment of Lisa Roumell as its deputy director. Until last year Ms. Roumell was a senior partner in DFW Management Company, a private equity investment fund. She will be responsible for the museum's daily operations and will also work with Lisa Phillips, director of the New Museum, in overseeing the new building project.
