HEADLINE: Runoff Is Likely After Argentines Vote Tomorrow 

BYLINE:  By LARRY ROHTER 

DATELINE: BUENOS AIRES, April 25 

 BODY:
With Argentines preparing to cast ballots for a new president on Sunday, candidates and voters alike are assuming that a runoff will be required, and that former President Carlos Saul Menem will be one of two survivors. As a result, the fierce battle for the second slot has suddenly intensified and become the focus of the campaign.
 According to a final series of opinion polls made public this week, five candidates are bunched so closely together that any two could move on to the runoff election, to be held on May 18 if no one receives a large enough percentage of the votes on Sunday. 
 But it now seems most likely that Nestor Kirchner, one of three Peronists in the race, or Ricardo Lopez Murphy, leader of the newly formed center-right Federal Recreate Movement, will face Mr. Menem in the second round. The last-minute surprise of the campaign is clearly Mr. Lopez Murphy, 51, a business consultant and economist trained at the University of Chicago. 
Barely a month ago he was languishing in fifth place, unfamiliar to most of the electorate and considered unlikely to perform strongly at the polls because of his unabashed enthusiasm for the policies that many Argentines blame for the collapse of the economy in December 2001. Those policies included budget cuts, relaxed regulation of businesses, the selling off of government assets and the opening of markets to foreign investment.
Roberto Bacman, a polltaker and political analyst, termed Mr. Lopez Murphy's rise "almost a miracle." Of the five main candidates, Mr. Bacman added, Mr. Lopez Murphy is the "only one who has exploited to the maximum his niche," that of the clear alternative to Peronism, and is showing growing strength in cities and among middle-class voters.
Under the Radical government elected in 1999, Mr. Lopez Murphy served for more than two years as defense minister and then for 17 days as economy minister, resigning in March 2001 when the government backed away from carrying out the budget-trimming measures he insisted were necessary. 
That act has enabled him to turn some of his deficiencies into strengths by arguing that he will always stand for principle over political expediency.
Known as the Bulldog because of his appearance and the aggressiveness with which he defends his positions and criticizes his rivals, Mr. Lopez Murphy has also benefited from what even his critics acknowledge is a clever media campaign. In one commercial the camera zooms in on Mr. Lopez Murphy's bushy mustache and toothy grin. "Would you entrust your child to a hospital where Kirchner was the doctor and Duhalde was the owner of the clinic?" he asks. The interim president, Eduardo Duhalde, is a Peronist, and Mr. Kirchner is his preferred candidate.
Many of Mr. Lopez Murphy's ideas about how to pull Argentina out of the worst economic crisis in its history are identical to those of Mr. Menem, who was president during most of the 1990's. But Mr. Lopez Murphy does not have the burden of being perceived as corrupt and unethical. Opinion polls indicate that this is Mr. Menem's biggest liability and that Mr. Lopez Murphy would defeat him handily if the two men met in a runoff.
Mr. Kirchner, in contrast, has staked out a position similar to that of President Luiz Inacio Lula da Silva in Brazil, positioning himself as the representative of the nationalist left to the point of referring to "my friend Lula" and implying, inaccurately, that he has Mr. da Silva's endorsement. A critic of Mr. Menem since the beginning of his career, he has also promised to modernize, cleanse and "renew" the Peronist movement from within.
Mr. Kirchner, 53, the governor of a thinly populated but oil-rich province in the Patagonia region, has emphasized the administrative skills that have given his province a budget surplus and virtually no unemployment.
"Of the three Peronists running, he is the only one who has not been president, and that is seen as a plus" said Felipe Noguera, a polltaker and political analyst. "He has reaped the benefit of his association with Duhalde but has managed to keep Duhalde at arm's length and is seen as his own man."
Hoping to blunt the recent surges by Mr. Menem and Mr. Lopez Murphy, Mr. Duhalde has taken a number of steps intended to help Mr. Kirchner. The government has announced a wage increase for civil servants, for example, and eased the terms on which middle-class bank depositors can gain access to long-frozen accounts.
Mr. Kirchner has announced that if victorious, he will retain Economy Minister Roberto Lavagna, who has become popular by halting inflation, the decline in the value of the peso and the contraction of the economy. Mr. Lavagna, in turn, has begun appearing in campaign advertisements in which he endorses Mr. Kirchner.
Mr. Kirchner has also redirected some of his criticisms away from Mr. Menem and toward Mr. Lopez Murphy, dismissing both as "Thatcherites" and puppets of the banks and multinational corporations that he holds responsible for the economic crisis. "The financial sector wants a manager, but Argentina wants a president," Mr. Kirchner said on Thursday.
He has also suggested that his new opponent has a fondness for authoritarian rule, noting that two of Mr. Lopez Murphy's closest advisers have links to the brutal military dictatorship that ruled this country from 1976 through 1983. Mr. Kirchner, on the other hand, belonged to a Peronist youth group that was forced to go underground, and he was briefly jailed during the dictatorship.
Voters can "opt for either of two models," Mr. Kirchner said this week. "They can opt for a model based on social exclusion, poverty, hunger and cutting benefits, or they can opt for social inclusion and institutional renewal."

HEADLINE: THE SARS EPIDEMIC: TORONTO; 
Canada Increases Pressure on World Health Organization to Lift Travel Advisory

BYLINE:  By CLIFFORD KRAUSS 

DATELINE: TORONTO, April 25 

 BODY:
Canada ratcheted up the pressure today to persuade the World Health Organization to reverse its advisory to travelers to avoid Toronto because of the outbreak of the highly contagious respiratory disease known as SARS.
 "We all believe that the World Health Organization came to the wrong conclusion," said Prime Minister Jean Chretien in a nationally televised news conference today after returning from a week's vacation in the Dominican Republic. 
 In a gesture intended to express confidence that Toronto was safe, Mr. Chretien said he was scheduling a cabinet meeting in Toronto on Tuesday, and would spend Monday night at a hotel here. "I will sleep very, very, very well," he said. 
Mr. Chretien made his remarks after calling the W.H.O. leader, Gro Harlem Brundtland, to protest the Wednesday decision, which is causing severe economic aftershocks here in Canada's financial center.
Canadian officials said the prime minister's conversation with Ms. Brundtland was private, but they noted that the two developed a good working relationship when Ms. Brundtland was prime minister of Norway in the early and mid-1990's.
There was no indication that Ms. Brundtland made any commitments one way or another.
"I don't think there will be a reversal," said Dick Thompson, spokesman for the communicable disease section of the W.H.O. But he added, "We re-evaluate travel information every day and in that sense we will be looking at it again regularly."
The Toronto death toll from SARS rose to 19 today, with 3 more deaths over the last day. There have been 257 probable and suspected cases in the area, a number that has actually gone down in recent days.
Canadian health officials, who are suddenly expressing optimism about controlling SARS, note that there has not been a new case reported outside the hospital system in more than a week. The disease, they say, has not broken out into the general community, and it is unlikely for a pedestrian to become sick with SARS.
But W.H.O. officials, who spoke on condition of anonymity, said they continued to believe that travel to Toronto posed a threat to world health, particularly for developing countries whose health care systems could not manage an outbreak of SARS introduced by someone who had traveled to an infected city. 
The officials said the health organization was coming under enormous political pressure from a country with traditionally warm ties to the United Nations. They suggested a possible reversal could be based on politics and not science.
The prime minister's call to Ms. Brundtland came after two days of telephone calls from cabinet officials and from the Ontario premier, Ernie Eves, who argued that the W.H.O. decision was based on faulty information that did not reflect an improving situation.
Mr. Eves said today that Canadian officials would present their case on Tuesday and "there will be a decision to make whether to lift the travel ban on Toronto or not."
The W.H.O. decision was based on determinations that several probable SARS cases in the Philippines, Australia and the United States were linked to people who had traveled to Canada. Canadian officials question whether many of the reported cases were actually SARS. Even if some were, they say, they do not reflect the current improvement. 
The United States Centers for Disease Control and Prevention did not agree with the W.H.O.'s decision, and has not added Toronto to its list of SARS-affected areas travelers should avoid.
Canada's frustration with a United Nations organization and its gratefulness for United States support come only a few weeks after Ottawa angered the Bush administration by not supporting the war in Iraq because it was not sanctioned by the Security Council.
"The Canadian predisposition toward multilateral institutions and antipathy to U.S. unilateralism has been briefly put on its head," said Robert A. Pastor, vice president for international affairs at American University and a senior official in the Carter White House, who was attending a conference in Toronto today.
The travel advisory has galvanized Canadians as few international issues have in years.
"I don't think they realize what the impact will be here," said Natalie Jurcic, 20, one of the owners of a clothing shop under the Royal York Hotel, whose business is off 30 percent because of worries over SARS. "Basically, the summer will be a write-off."
Few people in Toronto wear masks to protect themselves from SARS, and there has been only a modest impact on daily life outside of hospitals and businesses linked to tourism, restaurants or Chinese malls.
Fans who came to the Toronto Blue Jays game tonight said they were puzzled by reports that Major League Baseball has advised players to use their own pens when signing autographs. "That's ridiculous," said Sandy Munro, 52, a financial planner. "They're making a mountain out of a molehill. People with SARS don't go to the ballgame."

HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS; 
As Profit Falls, Samsung Turns More Aggressive

BYLINE:  By JAMES BROOKE 

DATELINE: SEOUL, South Korea, April 25 

 BODY:
The Samsung Electronics Company announced today that it would spend $500 million to upgrade its sole overseas chip plant, in Austin, Tex. Within hours of that announcement, Samsung's stock dropped 2.4 percent -- North Korean officials said that they had the capability to make nuclear bombs.
 Such are the gritty challenges that confront Samsung, the largest company in South Korea, a pulsating, high-tech country that shares a peninsula with a militarized, impoverished nation where few people are allowed to have telephones. 
 In China, Samsung's largest Asian export market, consumer demand is withering as a respiratory virus scares people away from markets and department stores where cellphones, DVD players and flat-screen televisions are languishing on the shelves. Around Asia, prices of computer chips, a major Samsung product, are falling as new American and European tariff barriers against Hynix, a Korean-government-supported rival, are expected to cause excess Korean-made chips to flood the region. 
Samsung sales in South Korea dropped by 28 percent this last quarter over the quarter last year. The decline seems to be a result of soaring credit card debt over the last year. About 500,000 South Koreans in their 20's, or about one in 15, are facing bankruptcy.
Last week, Samsung announced a 41 percent drop in profit for the quarter ended March 31, to $1.1 billion in operating profit. In response, Samsung increased its already aggressive investment budget to $5.65 billion, nearly two-thirds higher than last year's.
Since 1996, Samsung has been run by Yun Jong Yong, a soft-spoken engineer who seems to believe that a good dose of crisis and chaos will keep Samsung, South Korea's No. 1 company, agile and resourceful, fighting as if it were No. 3 when in many areas it has in fact become No. 1. And in many ways, Samsung's success is emblematic of Korea's rapid entry into the club of developed nations.
From a mass producer of cheap electronics a decade ago, Samsung is now the world's largest producer of memory chips and flat screens. Its market capitalization is now bigger than its Japanese rival, Sony. Last year, Samsung was the world's third-most-profitable electronics company, after General Electric and Microsoft.
And Samsung, a sponsor of the Olympics, has raised its profile as a global company. Last year, Interbrand, the brand consultant, ranked Samsung as the world's fastest- growing brand, ahead of Starbucks.
"Some people think that Samsung is a Japanese company," Chang Il Hyung, Samsung's top spokesman, said, gliding over 1,000 years of Korean-Japanese rivalry. "We don't care about that. Nationality is not that important to us. We are focusing on making Samsung a global market player."
Sony's sales volume still dwarfs Samsung's, but Sony's profitability is far lower. During the first quarter of this year, Samsung Electronics earned $942 million in net profit on $8 billion in sales. By comparison, Sony earned a similar amount, $963 million for the full fiscal year ended March 31, but that was on $62.3 billion in sales. On Thursday, Sony announced a profit on sales of 1.5 percent for the fiscal year, compared with 17.5 percent for Samsung last year.
In a reversal from a decade ago, when Japan dominated the world chip market, the nearly $500 million in profit recorded in the first quarter of this year by Samsung's semiconductor division is about equal to the forecasted combined profits for Japan's five largest chip makers -- Toshiba, NEC, Hitachi, Mitsubishi Electric and Fujitsu.
And Samsung has said it plans to invest about $3.4 billion in new chip plants and equipment this year. By contrast, the investment plans of Japan's five largest chip makers add up to about $2 billion. Last week, Sony announced that it would enter the chip market with a $1.67 billion investment. 
Among memory chip makers, Samsung is the world's only profitable major manufacturer. This year, it expects to sell $7 billion worth of memory chips.
Niche products like graphics chips for game consoles and flash-memory chips for cellphones and hand-held computers have helped Samsung make money in an industry plagued by overcapacity and declining demand. And last year, Samsung moved into a newer, more expensive chip, the DDR, or double data-rate chip. But with overcapacity in the industry, prices for the standard DRAM chips are down by almost 50 percent compared with the period a year ago.
"We hope that in the latter half of this year, chip demand will increase," Mr. Chang said. "In 1999, because of the Y2K problem, many PC's were replaced. Now is the time to replace them again."
Although Samsung is dependent on the memory-chip market, chips accounted for only 23 percent of Samsung's sales in the last quarter.
"We are into every kind of electronic product, from chips to cellphones," said Mr. Chang, adding that Samsung also makes home appliances like refrigerators and air-conditioners. 
But in a highly competitive sector, three of Samsung's main products -- chips, cellphones and liquid crystal display screens -- had increased sales last year, but with prices going down. The consumer credit problems have been an added burden. 
"They have to inject money, from $110 million to $470 million, to bail out their credit card company," Jon Chong-Hwa, Daewoo Securities' director of equity research, said referring to Samsung Card, which is 56 percent owned by Samsung Electronics.
In the fast-moving flat screen field, LG.Philips LCD, a South Korean-Dutch joint venture, nosed ahead of Samsung late last year to become the world's largest producer for a quarter. In a sharp counterattack, Samsung announced a month ago that it would invest $1 billion in a new flat-screen production plant, adding 60 percent to its next generation production capacity.
Of the $650 million in new investments announced last week, almost all the money is to go to making thin-film-transistor liquid crystal displays, the main component in L.C.D. monitors, laptop computer screens and some flat-panel televisions.
In mobile phones, Samsung has come from virtually nowhere to become the fastest growing of the world's big three manufacturers -- the other two being Nokia of Finland and Motorola of the United States. In the last two years, Samsung has doubled its share of the world market, selling $10 billion worth of cellphones last year. This year, it plans to increase its market share to sell 12 percent of the 435 million cellphones expected to be sold around the world. 
Aiming for the top end of the market, Samsung models increasingly feature color screens, cameras and more computing power than found in many laptops a decade ago.
Recalling the old attitude of expansion at any cost that gripped South Korean companies before the 1997 financial crisis, Mr. Chang said: "Before, we looked at market share, not profit. Now, profit and market share are important."
Some analysts say there will be more money to be made in the future with "dumb" phones, or simple inexpensive phones for a mass market. 
"China and India will be the world's largest cellphone markets," said David Roddy, the editor of the Korean Stock Market Newsletter. "They need cheap, simple phones."
Next month, Nokia will start merging its four Chinese manufacturing joint ventures into one company to strengthen its brand presence.
Even in South Korea, where about 70 percent of adults use the Internet, third-generation cellphones that will allow subway commuters to watch video-on-demand, for example, will not be marketed until 2005.
The push for speed has helped Samsung rise from a second-rate electronics manufacturer a decade ago to a technology leader. In the late 1980's, as a student of development economics at Yale, Mr. Chang searched a New Haven department store one afternoon for Samsung products. "The guy took me back to a corner and showed me stuff covered with dust," he recalled this week. "The attitude was: the function is good, but it is cheap."
But perceptions have changed. Mr. Chang attended an alumni function recently, and found an American peering at the business card on his jacket lapel. Mr. Chang said the man asked him, "How did Samsung become so successful in just 10 years?"

HEADLINE: AFTEREFFECTS: WHITE HOUSE MEMO; 
Bush Shows Looser Side in an Interview

BYLINE:  By ELISABETH BUMILLER 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, April 25 

 BODY:
Even when President Bush was in the middle of a meeting during the most critical moments of the war in Iraq, White House staff members would fetch him whenever the black-is-white Iraqi information minister, Muhammed Said al-Sahhaf, appeared on television. Mr. Bush, it turns out, was a big fan.
 "Somebody would say, 'He's getting ready to speak,' and I'd pop out of a meeting or turn and watch the TV," Mr. Bush said this week to Tom Brokaw of NBC News, describing himself less as the commander in chief and more as another American amused by the fantastical world of Mr. Sahhaf. Or as Mr. Bush put it, laughing, "He's my man." 
 The light moment was part of an unusual interview Mr. Bush gave this week that showed him as a looser and more reflective commander in chief than the one the public normally sees. While Mr. Bush presented himself to Mr. Brokaw as clearly in charge, unambivalent about power and well-versed in military developments, he was also relaxed enough to talk about his relationships with his father and God, and to admit to a modicum of uncertainty. 
The interview ranged from Iraq to President Jacques Chirac of France to the Dixie Chicks. It provided rare access to the president's thinking, and was at odds with the rigid portrait of the "resolute" president, the favorite adjective of Mr. Bush's advisers, put forth by the public relations types in the West Wing.
Mr. Bush acknowledged to Mr. Brokaw that his father, who led the nation into the 1991 Persian Gulf war, was nervous about the conflict that his son was commanding. But he said he talked to his father very little about the substance of the job and seemed to take pains to establish his independence from the 41st president.
"I really don't spend a lot of time hashing over policy with him," Mr. Bush said. "He knows that I am much better informed than he could possibly be."
The conversations, Mr. Bush said, "are more along the line of a dad and a son, a dad conveying to his son how much he loves him. Which is important. Even at the age of 56 years old it's important."
Mr. Bush described his mother, the former first lady who still orders him around at the family compound in Maine, as "feisty as ever," but said: "She doesn't follow everything in the news and the opinion like Dad does. He's an every-word man."
The president also spoke openly of his religious faith, and said it had not conflicted with his decision to wage a war in which Americans and Iraqis, including women and children, died. 
"Listen, any time you think about committing someone into combat is an emotional moment," Mr. Bush said. "You can't be detached from the human life involved with war."
Then he added: "I don't bring God into my life to be a political person; I ask God for strength and guidance."
The decision he made about war, he said, "is a decision I made based upon what I thought were the best interests of the American people. I was able to step back from religion, because I have a job to do. And I, on bended knee to the good Lord, asked him to help me to do my job in a way that's wise."
The interview was conducted on Air Force One in two parts on Thursday, between appearances that the president made in Ohio. Portions of the interview were broadcast on the NBC "Nightly News" on Thursday and today and a larger segment appeared in a one-hour NBC "Dateline" program tonight, "Commander in Chief: The White House at War." The White House made the entire transcript of the interview available late on Thursday.
Mr. Brokaw, the NBC anchor, said the president was enthusiastic throughout the interview.
"I was very struck by his eagerness to talk about this stuff, and how connected he was across the spectrum of it all," Mr. Brokaw said today. "Not just the military stuff, but the Middle East stuff and France and the global economy. And it just kind of spilled out of him."
On the Middle East, Mr. Bush said that "part of the frustrations that exist in the Middle East, and I recognize this, is the fact that there is no movement toward peace with the Palestinians."
He said that he had faith in the new prime minister, Mahmoud Abbas, called Abu Mazen, and that he would have him to the White House, but not if he was accompanied by the Palestinian leader Yasir Arafat.
"First of all, I looked at the history of Mr. Arafat," Mr. Bush said. "Now I saw what he did to President Clinton. There was no need to spend capital, unless you had an interlocutor who could deliver the Palestinian people toward peace. And I believe Abu Mazen is a man dedicated to peace."
On Mr. Chirac, who actively worked against the United States to oppose the war in Iraq, Mr. Bush said the French president would not be invited to his Texas ranch "any time soon." He added that he hoped that the French "won't be using their position within Europe to create alliances against the United States or Britain or Spain or any of the new countries that are the new democracies of Europe."
Mr. Bush also addressed the antiwar remarks of the Dixie Chicks, whose lead singer, Natalie Maines, said during a concert in London last month that she was "ashamed" that the president was a fellow Texan. Since then, the country superstars may have lost fans, but they are fighting back, in their fashion, by appearing naked on the cover of Entertainment Weekly.
"I mean, the Dixie Chicks are free to speak their mind," Mr. Bush said. "They can say what they want to say. And just because -- they shouldn't have their feelings hurt just because some people don't want to buy their records when they speak out. You know, freedom is a two-way street."

GRAPHIC: Photos: President Bush at prayer with marines at Camp Lejeune, N.C., in early April. In his NBC interview, he said that in taking the nation to war, he had asked God "to help me to do my job in a way that's wise."; The president said his father had been nervous about the war. His mother? As "feisty as ever." (Photographs by Associated Press)
